query: How does the OPS collaborate with primary care pediatric and specialty pediatric care providers as well as community behavioral clinicians in delivering behavioral health care services
response: The Outpatient Psychiatry Service (OPS) collaborates with primary care pediatric and specialty pediatric care providers, as well as community behavioral clinicians, in delivering behavioral health care services through consultative and co-management care models. After a comprehensive assessment of a patient's mental health, OPS clinicians provide treatment recommendations to the family. This treatment may be provided through the OPS or elsewhere. If long-term care is required, the OPS clinician works with behavioral health clinicians or primary care practitioners in the community to assume the care of the patient, once stabilized. This collaboration ensures a continuity of care and communication, improving the overall quality of care for patients with behavioral health needs.

query: How can a nurse access a surgical services ERAS protocol
response: To access a surgical service's ERAS (Enhanced Recovery After Surgery) protocol, a nurse can follow these steps:1. Go to the BCH Homepage.2. Navigate to Departments & Programs.3. Select Anesthesiology, Critical Care and Pain Medicine.4. Choose Clinical Guidelines & Policies.5. Click on Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS).During care coordination, the RN/NP staff should note "ERAS" in the following sections of the PAEF: Special Needs, Anesthesia Pre-Op Discussion, and Nursing Communication. They should also print a copy of the appropriate service-specific ERAS protocol and place it in the patient's paper chart for review at the pre-op visit.During the pre-op visit/phone call, the RN/NP should review the pre-op portion of the ERAS protocol and refer the family to the surgeon and/or anesthesiologist for additional questions related to ERAS.If ERAS is not noted on the OR booking sheet, contact the surgeon and/or associated PA/NP to confirm if the patient will be on the ERAS protocol.

query: What are the qualifications and certifications required for HSCT Hospitalists HH to provide overnight medical care for Pediatric Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant HSCT patients
response: The qualifications and certifications required for HSCT Hospitalists (HH) to provide overnight medical care for Pediatric Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant (HSCT) patients include:1. Being Board Eligible or Board Certified in Pediatrics.2. Successful completion of an accredited residency program.3. PALS (Pediatric Advanced Life Support) certification.4. Meeting all requirements per Boston Children's Hospital credentialing policies.For advance practice providers (APP), the requirements are:1. Completion of an accredited Physician Assistant or Nurse Practitioner degree-seeking program.2. PALS certification.3. Meeting all requirements per Boston Children's Hospital credentialing policies.The APP/HH is responsible for providing resident-level care for all HSCT service patients under the supervision of the HSCT attending. This care involves assessing patients, writing orders, documenting acute events with a note in the electronic medical record, and admitting new patients. However, they are not responsible for HSCT patients in the intensive care unit. If questions arise regarding HSCT patients in the ICU, they are directed to the HSCT attending.

query: What are the specific items included in the accurate Interventional Radiology count procedure for sharps guidewires and sponges
response: The Interventional Radiology count procedure for sharps, guidewires, and sponges involves several specific steps to ensure accuracy and patient safety.For sharps:1. Two individuals (technologist, physician, or nurse) audibly count and view all sharps and suture needles concurrently.2. The technologist maintains an accurate account of all sharps on the sterile field.3. All counted sharps remain within the sterile field during the procedure.4. If a counted sharp is passed off or inadvertently dropped off the sterile field, the IR technologist retrieves it in a safe manner to be included in the final count.5. All sharps are properly disposed of according to OSHA Bloodborne Pathogens Standards during end-of-case cleanup.For guidewires:1. Two individuals (technologist, physician, or nurse) audibly count and view all used guidewires concurrently.2. The technologist maintains an accurate account of all guidewires on the sterile field.3. All counted guidewires remain within the sterile field during the procedure.4. If a counted guidewire is inadvertently dropped off the sterile field, the IR technologist retrieves and isolates it from the field to be included in the final count.For sponges (only for procedures in which a surgical pocket is created):1. All sponges used must be x-ray detectable and kept in their original configuration.2. X-ray detectable sponges are counted audibly and viewed concurrently as they are separated and counted by two individuals.3. All counted sponges remain within the sterile field during the procedure.4. Maintain an ongoing tally of sponges throughout the procedure.5. All sponges are properly disposed of according to OSHA Bloodborne Pathogens Standards during end-of-case cleanup.If any count is incorrect, an extensive search is performed, and if the item is not found, the radiologist performs an x-ray or fluoroscopic image to confirm the item is not in the patient. Any unresolved counts are documented as incorrect in Radnet and in the IR physician post-procedural documentation.

query: How is average abandonment rate calculated in the context of a call centers automatic call distribution ACD system
response: The average abandonment rate in the context of a call center's Automatic Call Distribution (ACD) system is calculated as the percentage of calls that are terminated by the persons originating the call before they are answered by a staff member. This is typically measured after a certain period of time, such as 30 seconds after a pre-recorded message or greeting has ended. For example, if there are 100 calls and 10 of them are disconnected by the callers before they are answered by a staff member, the average abandonment rate would be 10%.

query: What is the process for obtaining consent for the administration of blood or blood components during a patients hospital stay
response: The process for obtaining consent for the administration of blood or blood components during a patient's hospital stay involves the following steps:1. Informed Consent: The patient or their parent/guardian must provide informed consent for the use of blood or blood products. This consent is typically included in the overall consent form for the procedure or treatment. It authorizes the use of blood or blood components throughout the duration of the hospital stay, as long as it is related to the procedure or treatment.2. Separate Consent: If the patient has not initially consented to the use of blood or blood products, a separate informed consent is required if the need for a blood transfusion arises later. This is usually done using a specific Blood Transfusion Consent form.3. Alternatives and Refusals: If a patient objects to the use of blood products for religious or other reasons, the clinical team should discuss alternatives that may be acceptable. If there are still concerns and it's necessary to provide blood or blood products, legal action may be considered to obtain authorization.4. Emergency Situations: In an emergency where consent cannot be obtained, blood or blood components may be administered. However, informed consent should be obtained as soon as possible.5. Minor Refusals: If a patient is a minor and refuses blood or blood components, the general counsel's office may be contacted to determine whether a court order requiring a blood transfusion is appropriate.6. Adult Refusals: If a competent adult patient refuses blood or blood components, their refusal should be honored.

query: What is the process for using a patients medical information including tissue implants or related biological materials for research purposes at Boston Childrens Hospital
response: The process for using a patient's medical information, including tissue implants or related biological materials for research purposes at Boston Children's Hospital, involves the following steps:1. The Primary Provider may use the patient's medical information, including tissue, implants, or related biological materials, for research into causes and cures for existing or future diseases.2. Any proposal to use the patient's identified medical information for research must first be presented to the Boston Children's Hospital Institutional Review Board (IRB).3. The IRB reviews and approves all research that involves human subjects conducted at Boston Children's Hospital. It determines if the research meets the criteria for human subject research, may be considered exempt, or requires expedited or full committee review.4. If the research involves interaction with a subject, a full research protocol is required.5. The patient and/or their parent/guardian must sign a separate research consent form if the provider seeks to use the patient's identified medical information for research.6. Medical information used for research must be de-identified, meaning it cannot have any identifying information about the patient.7. If a physician from another academic institution is involved in the research, a Reliance Agreement should be established between Boston Children's Hospital and the physician's primary institution.8. In accordance with Boston Children's Hospital medical staff bylaws and credentialing requirements, an appointment to the Boston Children's Hospital Medical Staff, House Staff, or Affiliating House Staff may be required for the unaffiliated physician if clinical information will be charted in the patient medical record.

query: What precautions should be taken when changing needleless connectors and who is required to wear a mask within 6 feet of the patient
response: When changing needleless connectors, the following precautions should be taken:1. Explain the procedure to the patient and/or parent.2. Disinfect a hard surface.3. Ensure the Central Venous Catheter (CVC) is clamped to prevent blood loss and air emboli.4. Everyone within 6 feet should wear a mask, including the patient if able. Note: Individuals in the other bedspace of a double room with closed curtain do not need a mask.5. Perform hand hygiene.6. Using a 10mL syringe filled with normal saline (NS) solution, prime the needleless connector and set it aside maintaining sterility.7. Open 3 packages of sterile 2x2 gauze.8. Open alcohol pads and place them on the gauze, touching only one corner of the alcohol pad.9. Perform hand hygiene again and don clean gloves.10. Scrub the connection between the catheter and needleless connector with an alcohol pad and gauze for 15 seconds and allow it to dry completely.11. Remove the needleless connector and perform a vigorous mechanical scrub to the catheter hub site with a new gauze and alcohol pad for 15 seconds and allow it to dry completely.12. Remove the protective end cover from the new needleless connector and screw it onto the hub. Do not touch the inner portion that fits into the CVC.13. Unclamp the CVC.14. Flush with 2-3 mL NS. Note: Implanted ports are flushed with 5 mL NS.15. Disconnect the syringe.16. Perform a vigorous mechanical scrub to the needleless connector with an alcohol pad for 15 seconds and allow it to dry completely.17. Either reconnect to infusion if clinically appropriate or follow additional steps for heparin locked CVCs.These precautions are based on the information provided in the sources, with source 1 being the most relevant. It's important to note that anyone within 6 feet of the patient should wear a mask during this procedure, as indicated in sources 1 and 3.

query: When should the Transfusion Medicine Physician or Designee be notified regarding any changes in the patients vital signs during the LDL Apheresis procedure
response: The Transfusion Medicine Physician or Designee should be notified immediately of any changes in the patient's vital signs during the LDL Apheresis procedure. The patient's vital signs should be monitored pre-procedure, hourly during the treatment, and post-procedure. query: What actions are taken by the IRB when a research protocol is conditionally approved and how are these actions documented
response: When a research protocol is conditionally approved by the IRB, it means that the IRB has approved the research study, but certain conditions need to be met before the research can proceed or continue. These conditions may include making specified changes to the research protocol or informed consent document, confirming specific assumptions or understandings about how the research will be conducted, or submitting additional documents.The IRB members decide whether the response is sent back to the IRB member primary and secondary reviewers or to the IRB analysts to confirm all changes and requests have been made. Once the conditions are satisfied, the IRB is able to make all of the determinations required for approval under the federal regulations.The date of IRB approval for a conditionally approved study remains the date the study was conditionally approved at a convened IRB meeting. The date the designated IRB reviewer determines that the research protocol has satisfied all conditions required is reflected in the action "Research Team Response Adequate".All responses to conditional approvals are placed back before the convened IRB for review. The voting actions and documentation for these reviews are the same as for other IRB meetings, with the vote taken and recorded, and any minority reports noted within the minutes.

query: What are the potential symptomatic responses a patient may experience during the adenosine medication challenge and how should they be treated
response: During an adenosine medication challenge, a patient may experience certain symptomatic responses. These can include hot flashes, feelings of impending doom, or a sinus pause. It's important to note that these reactions should be treated symptomatically. The procedure should be performed in a monitored setting with IV access, and vital signs should be checked every 3 minutes during the challenge. An external defibrillator/pacemaker should be at the bedside for immediate response if needed. However, the sources provided do not specify the exact treatments for each symptomatic response during an adenosine medication challenge.

query: When is inline suctioning considered for patients with an artificial airway and what factors are considered in making a suction plan for these patients
response: Inline suctioning is considered for patients with an artificial airway who require assisted ventilation. These patients are assessed by a nurse and a respiratory therapist at the beginning of each shift to formulate a suction plan based on the patient's condition. Factors considered in making a suction plan include the decision to perform open or closed suctioning, pre-oxygenation procedure, and the patient's specific clinical needs or diagnoses. High-risk patients, such as those with air leak syndrome, pulmonary hypertension, or low cardiac output syndrome, require a registered nurse and a registered respiratory therapist for suctioning procedures. The suction plan is reassessed each shift during rounds. Inline suction catheters are changed weekly and as needed.

query: What is the main focus of the Care of Patients After Termination of Pregnancy document
response: The main focus of the Care of Patients After Termination of Pregnancy document is to provide guidance on the perioperative considerations for patients who have recently undergone a termination of pregnancy. This includes verifying the termination of pregnancy before proceeding with any planned procedure, understanding the timeframe for scheduling elective surgeries post-termination, and ensuring proper documentation of the termination process and any potential complications. The document also emphasizes the importance of following up with the clinician who performed the termination to confirm its completion, or alternatively, using ßHCG levels as a method of verification.

query: How can the information in the document Enhanced Recovery After Surgery ERASpdf be utilized to improve patient care in the hospital
response: The document "Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS)" provides a framework for improving patient care in the hospital by implementing patient-centered, evidence-based, multidisciplinary team developed pathways. These pathways are designed to reduce the patient's surgical stress response, optimize their physiologic function, and facilitate recovery. They form an integrated continuum of care as the patient moves from home through the pre-hospital, preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative phases of surgery and back home again.To utilize this information, hospitals can develop service-specific ERAS protocols for various surgical procedures such as abdominal surgery, orthognathic procedures, and cardiac surgery, among others. These protocols should be noted on the OR booking sheet and communicated to all relevant staff.During care coordination, nursing staff should note "ERAS" in the special needs, anesthesia pre-op discussion, and nursing communication sections of the Pre-Anesthesia Evaluation Form (PAEF). A copy of the appropriate service-specific ERAS protocol should be printed and placed in the patient's paper chart for review at the pre-op visit.During the pre-op visit or phone call, the nursing staff should review the pre-op portion of the ERAS protocol with the patient and refer the family to the surgeon and/or anesthesiologist for additional questions related to ERAS.In addition, hospitals can participate in data collection related to ERAS, such as patient and family satisfaction via Press Ganey, National Database of Nursing Quality Indicators (NDNQI), and Quality Assurance Process Improvement (QAPI) strategies. This data can be used to monitor and track procedural outcomes, improve patient care, and identify opportunities for improvement.Overall, the implementation of ERAS protocols and the collection and analysis of related data can help improve patient care in the hospital by reducing surgical stress, optimizing physiologic function, and facilitating recovery.

query: What are the responsibilities of the primary and secondary reviewers for new protocol applications in the IRB process
response: The primary and secondary reviewers for new protocol applications in the IRB process have several key responsibilities.1. Expertise: At least one of the two reviewers must have the appropriate expertise to review the topic of the protocol. If there isn't appropriate expertise, an outside consultant will be sought or the protocol will be rescheduled for review when expertise is obtained.2. Review and Summary: The primary and secondary reviewers are responsible for a complete review and summary of the protocol application. They receive a Reviewer Worksheet that must be completed and uploaded in the IRB electronic system prior to the IRB meeting. This worksheet guides the reviewer comments and is structured to discuss the issues within the context of the regulatory criteria.3. Convened IRB Presentation: The primary and secondary reviewers present the protocol to the IRB at a convened meeting. The primary reviewer presents a brief summary of the protocol, followed by their comments. The secondary reviewer presents their comments only. Following the presentation by the primary and secondary reviewer, the IRB is invited to provide additional comments. All members are asked to review all protocols and informed consents in preparation for the discussion.The sources do not mention any specific responsibilities unique to the secondary reviewer beyond presenting their comments at the convened IRB meeting. Both primary and secondary reviewers are expected to have read and be prepared to discuss all protocols and submissions before a meeting.

query: In what instances should humidified supplemental oxygen therapy be administered to patients in the PACU
response: Humidified supplemental oxygen therapy should be administered to patients in the PACU (Post Anesthesia Care Unit) in certain instances, primarily when patients have undergone specific procedures or have particular conditions. These include patients who have had laryngoscopies, bronchoscopies, esophagoscopies, laser excisions of laryngeal or tracheal papillomas, and tonsillectomies. Additionally, any patient with upper airway compromise, specifically those with stridor or a history of croup, should receive humidified oxygen therapy. The therapy should be administered to maintain oxygen saturation as needed, typically above 90% for patients not in distress, and above 95% for patients who are in distress or have high HASS scores. A prescriber order is generally required for the administration of supplemental oxygen, except in emergency situations.

query: What are the common risk factors for acquiring CarbapenemResistant Enterobacteriaceae CRE in the hospital setting
response: The common risk factors for acquiring Carbapenem-Resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE) in the hospital setting include having invasive medical devices such as ventilators, urinary catheters, and IV catheters, as well as being on long-term antibiotics. Transmission of CRE can occur via direct or indirect contact with infected individuals, or through contaminated water or food. Patients in the hospital setting are more likely to acquire CRE compared to the general community. It is important to note that CRE bacteria have become resistant to most available antibiotics, making infections difficult if not impossible to treat, and are associated with high mortality rates (up to 50%). Therefore, CRE is a serious threat to public health.

query: What are the administration guidelines for the antifibrinolytic agent Aminocaproic Acid Amicar for patients receiving ECMO
response: The administration guidelines for the antifibrinolytic agent Aminocaproic Acid (Amicar) for patients receiving ECMO include:1. Indications:   - Prematurity (e.g., < 37 weeks gestational age)   - Following repair of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (for 72 hours)   - Post-operative or post-procedure bleeding   - Patients with a pre-existing Intraventricular Hemorrhage (IVH)   - Severe hypoxia and/or acidosis (pH ≤ 7.10 at the time of cannulation)   - Patients who received CPR prior to cannulation2. Dose and Administration:   - Loading Dose: 100mg/kg (max 5000mg/dose) via peripheral IV   - Maintenance Dose: 30 mg/kg/hr continuous infusion via the ECMO circuit. Maximum Dose: 1250 mg/hr (30 g/day)3. Considerations:   - When used for ongoing bleeding, consider an additional loading dose following ECMO circuit changes   - Continue infusion throughout the ECMO course for patients with pre-existing IVH   - When used for postoperative bleeding, may be discontinued after 72 hours if coagulation management is stable and there is no evidence of active bleeding   - Do NOT infuse in the same line as Parenteral Nutrition (PN)

query: How often should the CCTT RN document ECMO flow rpm and sweep gas and where should this documentation be recorded
response: The CCTT RN should document ECMO flow, rpm, and sweep gas every hour and with any changes on the neonatal/pediatric transport database (source 1). It's important to note that the ECMO specialist may make recommendations to sweep gas changes based on blood gas results (source 2). Routine arterial blood gases should be taken a minimum of every 12 hours and every time a change in sweep gas is made (source 3). The documentation of these parameters is crucial for the safe and effective operation of the ECMO circuit.

query: How is voting documented at a convened IRB meeting and what is the process for minority reporting

The reviewer has access to the entire protocol file via the CHeRP system.The IRB voting actions typically include accepting the event, requesting additional information, or suspending recruitment or the entire protocol if necessary. The IRB also votes on whether the event meets the criteria for reporting.Following the discussion, the primary and secondary reviewers suggest a voting action. The IRB Chair then calls for a committee vote. The Chair usually continues the discussion until a consensus is reached, but a vote can be called at any time.The voting procedures apply to the review and voting process for amendments and revisions as well. Each amendment is assigned a primary and a secondary reviewer, who complete a Reviewer Worksheet and submit it at the end of the meeting.As for the process of minority reporting, the sources do not provide specific information on how it is documented or carried out during a convened IRB meeting.

query: According to the hospital policy what is the basis for sleepstage scoring in the Adult MWT Protocol
response: The basis for sleep stage scoring is not explicitly mentioned in the provided sources. However, the sources do provide information about the Adult Multiple Sleep Latency Test (MWT) protocol. According to the sources, the MWT should be conducted when a patient is clinically stable, and any known sleep disorders are well established and effectively treated. The patient's sleep should be adequately documented, preferably by a sleep diary and actigraphy for 2 weeks before testing. The use of tobacco, caffeine, medications, and other substances should be determined before the MWT. The test should be performed after the patient's major sleep period and may be preceded by a Polysomnogram (PSG) at the discretion of the sleep clinician. The MWT trials typically last 40 minutes and the protocol strictly adheres to the AASM Practice Guidelines.

query: What are the steps to be taken if a patient has gross hematuria during Cyclophosphamide administration
response: If a patient has gross hematuria during Cyclophosphamide administration, the following steps should be taken:1. Notify the house officer immediately.2. The clinician should check for bladder distension, adequate cardiac perfusion, assessing blood pressure, checking for pulses, and assessing heart rhythm.3. The clinician should discuss the situation with the HSCT fellow or attending.4. If the exam is negative, the clinician should order a 10 cc/kg NS bolus and consider increasing the IVF rate after the bolus.5. The clinician should review the patient's labs and resend electrolytes and osmolality if indicated.6. If there is no urine output one hour after the bolus, the clinician should order Furosemide (Lasix) 0.5 mg/kg IV x 1.7. If there is no urine output 2 hours after Lasix, the clinician should check results of serum electrolytes and osmolality sent earlier and review with HSCT fellow or attending. If no significant SIADH (Na < 128), consider bladder ultrasound. Also, consider Foley placement.8. If the patient has heme moderate gross hematuria, the RN should send a urinalysis. The clinician should review the last platelet count and consider rechecking the platelet count. The clinician should discuss the situation with the fellow or attending including the possibility of increasing the IVF rate.

query: What are the recommended methods for administering enteral feedings and what should be avoided to prevent inadvertent administration via the intravenous route
response: The recommended methods for administering enteral feedings include:1. Using an enteral feeding pump, such as Kangaroo® or Medfusion®, especially for patients who cannot tolerate gravity feeds administered over 20 to 30 minutes.2. Administering enteral feedings through enteral syringe feeding tubing or through an enteral feeding bag attached directly to the feeding tube.3. For bolus feedings, they should be given per prescriber order instead of continuous feeds whenever possible.4. Ensuring oxygen and suction equipment are available at the patient bedside at all times.To prevent inadvertent administration of enteral feeding via the intravenous route, it is important to:1. Not use intravenous tubing for enteral feeds.2. Use an enteral syringe and enteral syringe feeding tubing via the Medfusion ® enteral syringe pump to administer human milk feeds and formulas with oil added. When feasible, consider changing the syringe every 2 hours before changing the delivery method to an enteral feeding bag.Additionally, for post-pyloric tube feedings, it is generally recommended to deliver them continuously via an enteral pump and avoid bolus feedings as the duodenum and jejunum cannot readily accommodate the volume of fluid that the stomach can hold, which may result in pain and potential perforation of the intestine. Also, it is recommended to limit medication administration due to increased risk of tube occlusion and medication absorption concerns. Consult pharmacy as needed and flush every 4 hours with water to maintain patency.

query: What services are offered by the Outpatient Psychiatry Service OPS for children and adolescents
response: The Outpatient Psychiatry Service (OPS) offers a range of services for children and adolescents. These include comprehensive mental health evaluations and treatment for various conditions affecting mental, emotional, and social health. The process begins with a diagnostic evaluation to understand the patient's mental health condition.Following the evaluation, clinicians provide treatment recommendations tailored to the child and family. These recommendations may involve evidence-based psychotherapies such as Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and Parent-Child Interaction Therapy (PCIT), which can be delivered individually or in group settings. Additionally, psychopharmacology may be recommended when necessary.These services are provided both in-person and virtually, depending on an agreement with the patients and families. The OPS also collaborates with primary care pediatric and specialty care providers, as well as community behavioral clinicians, to provide comprehensive care.The OPS sees patients aged 4 through 17. For patients less than 4 years old or between 18 and 21 years old, referrals are reviewed by the OPS Director to determine the best setting for their clinical needs.It's important to note that certain referrals, such as those primarily concerned with immediate safety risks, autism, eating disorders, substance abuse, non-complex ADHD, court involvement, and learning disability testing, are not typically appropriate for an OPS evaluation and are triaged elsewhere.

query: How should the catheter be flushed after suctioning and what should be done when thick secretions are present in small diameter airways
response: After suctioning, the catheter should be flushed with sterile normal saline (NS) until the fluid appears clear in the catheter window. When thick secretions are present in small diameter airways (less than 4.0 mm), consider instilling 0.5 to 1 ml of sterile NS directly into the artificial airway. This should be done sparingly and only when indicated and tolerated by the patient. To instill the NS, advance the catheter just into the endotracheal tube (ETT) or tracheostomy and instill the NS. Then, pull the catheter back to the resting position and allow 2-4 breaths to be delivered, which directs the NS down the ETT. Suctioning can then be resumed as described earlier. Remember to monitor the patient's vital signs throughout the procedure and provide post-procedure hyper-oxygenation when indicated.

query: According to the PHS Policy what is the focus of the policy on Humane Care and Use of Laboratory Animals
response: The PHS Policy on Humane Care and Use of Laboratory Animals focuses on ensuring the humane treatment of all vertebrate species used in research. A major aspect of this policy is minimizing pain and distress for these animals whenever possible. The Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC) plays a key role in implementing this policy.The policy requires that all procedures with the potential to cause pain or distress must be justified and alternatives that could reduce pain or distress must be explored. If a procedure is expected to cause more than momentary pain or distress, the investigator must provide information on what steps will be taken to alleviate this, such as the use of analgesics.The policy also emphasizes the importance of recognizing signs of pain and distress in animals, and provides guidelines for this. It requires that all possible measures must be taken to minimize animal discomfort and distress.In cases where pain and distress cannot be relieved due to the nature of the experiment, the policy requires that explicit parameters be established to determine when an animal should be euthanized to prevent extreme or unnecessary suffering.The policy further requires that all personnel involved in animal care and use are appropriately qualified and trained to perform their duties, including the humane care and use of animals. This includes providing adequate training in the humane methods of animal maintenance and experimentation, the use of anesthetics, analgesics, and tranquilizers, and the reporting of deficiencies in animal care and treatment.In summary, the PHS Policy on Humane Care and Use of Laboratory Animals is designed to ensure that all vertebrate animals used in research are treated humanely, with a focus on minimizing pain and distress. It requires justification for any procedures that may cause pain or distress, the use of appropriate measures to alleviate pain and distress, and the establishment of parameters for euthanasia in cases where pain and distress cannot be relieved. It also requires appropriate training for all personnel involved in animal care and use.

query: How should the team be involved in the sepsis huddle at the bedside as outlined in the hospital policy
response: The team should be involved in the sepsis huddle at the bedside as follows:1. The Attending Physician, NP/resident, bedside RN, charge RN/nurse manager, and parents (if appropriate) should participate in the bedside huddle. The huddle can also be joined via call if the physician cannot be at the bedside.2. The NP/PAs/Residents/Fellows should be notified of a red CHEWS score and conduct a bedside huddle to discuss the plan with the team. They should also reassess the patient at the bedside every 4 hours if the CHEWS score persists.3. The Surgeon of the Day (SOD)/ Surgeon of the Week (SOW)/Department of Pediatrics Attending (DOP) ICU STAT/Code Blue team should immediately assess and triage patients with an acute change in condition.4. Communication about a red CHEWS score can be done by a resident, fellow, NP, PA, or RN.5. A bedside huddle should be conducted with any escalation in CHEWS scores, and a plan of care should be agreed upon and documented.6. The team should define physiologic or other criteria that would denote deterioration and warrant further intervention with the agreement of the direct care team.7. A team huddle should occur at least once daily for patients with persistent red CHEWS scores.8. If a parent/guardian feels something is not right with their child, their concerns should be addressed through the use of the nursing and physician chain of command. They can also initiate the Family Activated Rapid Response for their child if they have significant concerns about their child's condition.9. The charge RN or designee should assign team responsibilities after the huddle.10. The huddle outcome should be documented in the sepsis trigger tool dropdown. If there is a concern for sepsis, the provider should use the sepsis power plan to facilitate timely ordering, delivery, and administration of antibiotics.11. Contingency planning with the team should be done, and the family should be updated at the bedside.

query: When can a splitnight study be performed and what specific criteria must be met during the diagnostic portion of the study before initiation of PAP
response: A split-night study can be performed when ordered by a sleep staff physician or another physician with their approval. This study is used to diagnose sleep apnea and determine effective PAP treatment. Before initiating PAP during the diagnostic portion of the study, certain criteria must be met:1. A minimum of 2 hours of diagnostic PSG (Polysomnography) with an AHI (Apnea-Hypopnea Index) of at least 30.2. Split-night studies may also be considered if the AHI is between 15 and 40, based on clinical judgment.3. If the AHI is greater than 20 and there are documented symptoms such as excessive daytime sleepiness, impaired cognition, mood disorders, insomnia, documented hypertension, ischemic heart disease, or a history of stroke.4. CPAP (Continuous Positive Airway Pressure) can be initiated during the diagnostic PSG as an emergency measure if multiple apneas lead to severe oxygen desaturation (below 70%) and/or prolonged apneas (more than 60 seconds) are observed during the diagnostic PSG, with a minimum of 2 hours of sleep documented.5. There must be at least 3 hours remaining for the CPAP titration.These guidelines follow the AASM (American Academy of Sleep Medicine) practice parameters.

query: How should the surface of the rubber closure on a glass evacuated container be prepared before transferring the sterile solution
response: To prepare the surface of the rubber closure on a glass evacuated container before transferring the sterile solution, follow these steps:1. Remove the aluminum protective cap on the bottle.2. Clean the surface of the rubber closure with an alcohol swab.3. Allow the alcohol to dry completely. This is important to maintain sterility.After these steps, you can proceed with the transfer of the sterile solution using aseptic technique. This involves inserting a needle at a 60 degree angle to the rubber closure, with the bevel edge pointed upward and applying slight pressure away from the bevel. Once the needle has penetrated the closure, quickly move the needle to the vertical position and complete the penetration.The solution should then flow freely into the empty evacuated container. The flow of solution can be regulated by adjusting the clamp on the transfer set.These instructions are based on the information provided in sources 1 and 2, which are the most relevant to your query.

query: How are amendmentsrevisions that do not meet the criteria for expedited review handled during a convened IRB meeting
response: Amendments or revisions that do not meet the criteria for expedited review are handled during a convened IRB meeting. These revisions are placed on the agenda for the meeting and all members are provided with a copy of the amendment/revision request form, which includes the proposed changes and the rationale for the change. Each amendment is assigned a primary and a secondary reviewer, who are given a Reviewer Worksheet to complete and submit at the end of the meeting. The CHeRP system allows members to review the sections of the SmartForm and attached materials that have been changed. Revised consents and recruitment notices are submitted in tracked changes to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the review process. The voting procedures applied to the initial review also apply to the review and voting process for amendments/revisions.

query: How should a positive response to MetaNeb therapy be monitored and what schedule should be followed if the patient shows improvement
response: The monitoring of a positive response to MetaNeb therapy should involve evaluating the effectiveness of the procedure and patient outcomes. This includes noting changes in the patient's lung sounds, rate and depth of respiration, as well as heart rate (Source 1).If a patient shows a positive response to MetaNeb therapy, it is recommended to continue on a schedule of BID (twice a day) or QID (four times a day) (Source 1).The therapy is no longer indicated when a patient demonstrates an absence or reduction of secretions, there is an absence or reduction of atelectasis or consolidation on chest exam, bilateral breath sounds have cleared or are significantly improved, or the patient becomes ambulatory (Source 1).In addition, general monitoring should include continuous monitoring of heart rate, respiratory rate, and SpO2 (Source 2).Please note that the specifics of the monitoring and schedule may vary depending on the patient's condition and the healthcare provider's recommendations. Always consult with a healthcare professional for medical advice.The other sources provided do not seem to contain relevant information to answer this query.

query: What are the clinical needs or diagnoses that require the use of the High Risk Suctioning Procedure as outlined in the hospital policy
response: The High Risk Suctioning Procedure is used for patients with an artificial airway who require assisted ventilation and meet certain high risk criteria. These patients are assessed by a registered nurse and a respiratory therapist at the beginning of each shift, and a suctioning plan is made based on the patient's condition.The following diagnoses or clinical needs are considered high risk and require the High Risk Suctioning Procedure:1. Air leak syndrome2. Congenital diaphragmatic hernia3. HFOV/HFJV (High Frequency Oscillatory Ventilation/High Frequency Jet Ventilation)4. Critical airway5. Pulmonary hypertension6. Inhaled anesthetic or heliox therapy7. iNO (Inhaled Nitric Oxide)8. Shunted single ventricle patient9. Low cardiac output syndrome (LCOS)10. Hemodynamic instability requiring multiple vasopressors11. PEEP dependent patients that have demonstrated desaturation upon disconnection from the ventilator or have a prolonged recovery time12. < 1 year of age for the first 24 hours following cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB)13. Known or risk for left atrial (LA) hypertension as identified by CICU attending and/or attending surgeon

query: How is quorum defined for a convened IRB meeting and what happens if a quorum is lost during a meeting
response: A quorum for a convened Institutional Review Board (IRB) meeting is defined as having more than half of the IRB members present. This is necessary for the meeting to take place and for any actions to be taken. If a quorum is lost during the meeting, no further actions can be taken.The IRB members should represent various roles, including a scientific member, a member whose primary concerns are non-scientific, a member not affiliated with the hospital, and a member who represents the general perspective of subjects. A physician member must be present during the review of any clinical research study that involves the use of a Food and Drug Administration-regulated drug, device, or biologic.Consultants can be used to provide appropriate review or education, but they do not count towards the quorum and cannot vote. They must sign a confidentiality agreement and cannot have any conflict of interest.These guidelines are set to ensure that the IRB has the appropriate expertise to review clinical research protocols, taking into consideration the medical, emotional, social, and psychological needs of the participants.

query: What is the immediate action to be taken upon receiving information regarding a suspicious package or bomb threat at North Dartmouth as per the hospital policy
response: Upon receiving information about a suspicious package or bomb threat at North Dartmouth, the immediate actions to be taken as per the hospital policy are:1. This involves calling 9-911 immediately to notify local emergency responders, providing their name and exact location, and describing the nature and specifics of the threat.2. The employee who receives the bomb threat should then inform the North Dartmouth Manager that they have notified 9-11 of the threat. The North Dartmouth Manager will meet the police to assist with the search and/or evaluation.3. Based on the credibility of the threat, the police and the North Dartmouth Manager will decide if the Evacuation Plan needs to be activated. If it does, the North Dartmouth Manager or their designee will inform patients, visitors, providers, and staff about the need for evacuation.4. If a suspicious package is discovered, the discoverer should not move, crush, shake, or open the package. They should contact the local police immediately.5. query: How is patient and family satisfaction measured at CAIR and what specific tool is used for this purpose
response: Patient and family satisfaction at CAIR is measured through various methods, with a specific emphasis on the use of the Press Ganey survey. query: What procedures are performed in the Gastroenterology Procedure Unit
response: The Gastroenterology Procedure Unit (GPU) performs a variety of gastrointestinal procedures that are both diagnostic and therapeutic in nature. These procedures are crucial for the subspecialty care of patients with gastrointestinal, hepatobiliary, pancreatic, and nutritional disorders. Some of the procedures performed in the GPU include endoscopic procedures, colonoscopy, biopsy, Esophageal impedance studies, and lactose breath testing. The GPU also provides anesthesiologist-administered sedation and anesthesia for children and young adults. Additionally, the GPU supports the Sedation Service, which provides procedural sedation for inpatients and outpatients undergoing minor procedures such as placement of PICC lines, lumbar puncture, bone marrow biopsy, skin biopsy, and joint aspiration. The staffing and patient care in the GPU are guided by the principles of the Society of Gastroenterology Nurses and Associates (SGNA) and the American Society of Peri Anesthesia Nurses (ASPAN).

query: What is the definition of Enhanced Recovery after Surgery ERAS u00ae  according to the American Association of Nurse Anesthetists
response: Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS®) is a patient-centered, evidence-based approach developed by multidisciplinary teams to improve surgical outcomes. According to the American Association of Nurse Anesthetists, ERAS pathways aim to reduce the patient's surgical stress response, optimize their physiologic function, and facilitate recovery. These care pathways form an integrated continuum as the patient moves from home through the pre-hospital/preadmission, preoperative, intraoperative, and postoperative phases of surgery and back home again. ERAS protocols are tailored to specific surgical procedures and may include various elements such as preoperative patient education, optimization of nutritional and physical status, standardized anesthetic and analgesic regimens, early mobilization, and coordinated discharge planning.

query: What is the definition of a consultation as per the hospitals Medical Staff Consultations PolicyProcedure
response: A consultation, as defined by the Medical Staff Consultations Policy, is a process where an attending medical staff member seeks advice or assistance from another medical staff member, referred to as the "Medical Staff Consultant" or "Consultant", on specific issues related to a patient's diagnosis or management. The consultant evaluates the patient in a timely manner, based on the urgency of the situation, and provides appropriate guidance to the attending medical staff member. This includes answering specific questions, recommending procedures, diagnostic tests, medical or surgical management, and additional consultations if needed. The attending medical staff member is responsible for defining the question or issue to be addressed by the consultant, providing all relevant background information, and evaluating the consultant's recommendations based on the patient's overall condition. The level and frequency of communication between the consultant and the attending medical staff member is determined by the level of acuity of the patient and the nature of the issues addressed in the consult.

query: What are the options for using the MetaNeb Circuit and what are the components required for each option

query: What is the process for incorporating the comments of the Respondent and Complainant in the draft report during a review of research misconduct
response: The process for incorporating the comments of the Respondent and Complainant in the draft report during a review of research misconduct is as follows:1. The panel conducts its review and creates a draft report.2. This draft report is shared with the Respondent and, if appropriate, the Complainant.3. The Respondent and Complainant are given the opportunity to review and comment on the draft report.4. Their written responses are considered and addressed by the panel.5. The final investigation report includes these responses, which are attached to it.For joint proceedings with HMS, the final report is sent for consideration of the HMS Standing Committee on Faculty Conduct before sharing it with the DO at each institution. Throughout the proceeding, the Respondent has the opportunity to present their case and review and comment on draft reports generated by the Inquiry proceeding. The Respondent also has access to the evidence included in the panel report.

query: What are the qualifications required for dietitians to provide nutritional care to patients in this hospital according to the policy

query: What are the steps for confirming proper placement of a postpyloric feeding tube and when can the tube be used for feeding
response: The steps for confirming proper placement of a postpyloric feeding tube involve first inserting the tube through the nose and advancing it to the first mark (gastric). The patient is then rolled into an extreme right decubitus position to facilitate passage of the tube from the stomach into the duodenum. The tube is advanced to the second mark (duodenal) while simultaneously insufflating a small volume of air. A "subtle" give may be noted as the feeding tube crosses the pylorus. The tube is then advanced another 5-10 cm to the third mark to ensure jejunal or distal duodenal placement. A positive "snap test" is performed by insufflating 3-5 mL of air into the tube and then pulling back on the syringe plunger. Auscultation of air over the right upper quadrant of the abdomen and absence of sounds over the distal esophagus is also performed. Finally, an abdominal x-ray (KUB) is obtained to confirm proper tube position. The tube should not be used for feeding until post-pyloric placement is confirmed by KUB and communicated by the prescriber.Sources: 1, 2

query: What is the definition of an Adverse Event according to the hospitals policy
response: An Adverse Event, according to the hospital's policy, is any occurrence or event which results in an unanticipated death, or an event in which major and permanent loss of function (not related to the natural course of the patient's illness or condition) occurs. It also includes any event that places a patient at increased risk of harm, or unplanned significant change in medical or surgical management not related to the patient’s underlying condition.Adverse events are to be reported within 24 hours of becoming aware of the event through the hospital’s internal web-based Safety Event Reporting System (SERS). Any hospital employee, volunteer, Medical Staff member, or House Staff member may report an adverse event. If staff are uncertain whether an event is a reportable adverse event, they should err on the side of reporting.The hospital also conducts a root cause analysis to understand the causes that underlie the event and make changes in the organization's systems and processes to reduce the probability of such an event in the future. The goal of this policy is to have a positive impact in improving patient care, reducing the probability of a reoccurrence of the event, and increasing general awareness and strategies for prevention.

query: Why is the use of the Reviewer Worksheet mandatory for the primary and secondary reviewers in the IRB electronic system

query: What are the steps involved in bypassing ultrafiltration of bank blood before a blood transfusion

query: How does the specialty pharmacy ensure patient access to services according to hospital policy
response: The specialty pharmacy at Boston Children's Hospital ensures patient access to services through several methods, as outlined in the provided sources.Firstly, the pharmacy is responsible for optimizing patient care through medication management, ensuring the safety, appropriateness, and effectiveness of pharmaceutical care related to specialty products (source 1).When a prescription is received, the pharmacist reviews all medication orders for appropriateness, clarity, and accuracy. If the prescription is for a limited distribution drug that the pharmacy does not have access to, the patient is notified and the prescription is transferred to a pharmacy that can fill it (source 2 and source 3).The pharmacy also assists with the prior authorization process. A clinic-specific pharmacy liaison performs a benefits investigation to determine the patient’s prescription insurance and contacts the insurer to determine if a prior authorization is required. If it is, the liaison works with the prescriber and insurer to complete and submit the request form, and monitors its status (source 2).In terms of financial assistance, the liaison attempts to obtain financial aid through manufacturer programs, non-profit foundations, and government-sponsored programs if the patient's out-of-pocket cost is greater than five dollars. The liaison also works directly with the patient to obtain necessary financial information or signatures, and with the pharmacy to ensure the aid is applied to the patient's copay (source 2).The pharmacy has specific guidelines for accepting a patient, including living in the defined service area and having the ability to pay for services. All services are provided utilizing acceptable professional procedures and performed by appropriately trained personnel (source 3).The pharmacy also provides post-enrollment patient information, including details about patient access to pharmacy information and support services, patient financial responsibilities, and how to contact patient support services and obtain prescription order status (source 4).In summary, the specialty pharmacy at Boston Children's Hospital ensures patient access to services through careful prescription review, assistance with prior authorization and financial aid, clear communication about patient responsibilities, and provision of ongoing support and information.

query: What are the criteria for making a finding of Research Misconduct according to the hospitals policy
response: The criteria for making a finding of Research Misconduct according to the hospital's policy are:1. The allegation must fit the definition of Research Misconduct, which includes Fabrication, Falsification, or Plagiarism in proposing, performing, or reviewing research, or in reporting research results.2. The allegation must represent a significant departure from accepted practices of the research community.3. The misconduct must be proven by a preponderance of evidence.The investigation report should specify whether Falsification, Fabrication, or Plagiarism occurred, who committed it, and whether it was intentional, knowing, or in reckless disregard of the truth. The report may also include recommendations for administrative actions or other appropriate sanctions. The draft report will be shared with the Respondent (and Complainant if appropriate) to review; their written responses will be considered and addressed by the panel and attached to the final Investigation report.

query: What factors does the Department of Children and Families DCF consider when making a determination about providing psychiatric treatment or administering Psychotropic medications to a child under their care and protection
response: The Department of Children and Families (DCF) considers several factors when deciding about providing psychiatric treatment or administering psychotropic medications to a child under their care and protection.Firstly, DCF distinguishes between routine and extraordinary care. Psychiatric treatment or psychotropic medications are typically considered extraordinary care due to their complexity, potential side effects, and intrusiveness.In such cases, DCF must provide informed consent for all medications, except for the use of anti-psychotic medication. For anti-psychotic medications, DCF needs to seek prior judicial approval.The decision-making process takes into account the clarity of the medical opinion on the need for the proposed care, the extent of conflicting interests between the decision-makers and what is in the best interests of the child, and the extent of prior judicial involvement in healthcare decision-making on behalf of the child.If the child is in DCF custody because of a voluntary placement, including a Child Requiring Assistance (CRA) application, the consent decision remains with the parents.In an emergency situation, where failure to medicate will result in a substantial likelihood of physical harm to the child or others, medication can be provided without prior consent. However, the facts supporting the psychiatrist's judgment that an emergency exists should be documented in the patient's medical record.These guidelines ensure that the best interests of the child are prioritized while making decisions about psychiatric treatment and the administration of psychotropic medications.

query: What documentation is required to confirm the placement of the feeding tube prior to use
response: The documentation required to confirm the placement of a feeding tube prior to use includes:1. Radiographical confirmation: An abdominal x-ray (KUB) is required after feeding tube placement to confirm proper tube position. This should be ordered and obtained to confirm placement prior to use.2. Documentation of the procedure: The size and length of the tube, patient tolerance of the procedure, results of the snap test, and the best location of auscultation of air after insufflation should be documented.3. Exit point marking: The number marking on the feeding tube at the nares should be documented. This can be done in the patient's chart, on a flowsheet, or in electronic documentation.4. Prescriber order: The order for the feeding tube placement and any medications related to the insertion should be verified.5. Confirmation of appropriate exit point marking: After insertion or upon arrival to the general unit, confirm appropriate exit point marking at the nare and document the length and size of tube in the patient's chart.

query: What are the different types of safe patient handling equipment available to assist with patient mobilization
response: The different types of safe patient handling equipment available to assist with patient mobilization include:1. Ceiling lifts: These are overhead devices that can help lift and move patients between different surfaces, such as from a bed to a wheelchair.2. Floor-based portable lifts, also known as Hoyer lifts: These are mobile devices that can be used to lift and transfer patients who have limited mobility.3. Air-assisted technology: This includes devices like the HoverMatt, which uses air to help reduce friction and make it easier to move patients.4. Lateral transfer devices: These include slide boards and rollboards, which can help patients move from one surface to another, such as from a bed to a stretcher.5. Slide sheets: These are special sheets that can be used to help reposition patients in bed or assist with lateral transfers. An example is the Comfort Glide.These devices should be selected based on the patient's needs, their ability to participate, the total lifting weight, the handling task, and the physical environment. It's also important to ensure that the equipment is in working order and that proper body mechanics are used when lifting and moving patients.

query: What steps should be taken to preserve research records and evidence in the event of research misconduct
response: To preserve research records and evidence in the event of research misconduct, the following steps should be taken:1. The Research Integrity Officer (RIO) should work with relevant departments, such as Information Services, to locate, take custody, inventory, and secure relevant research records and evidence. This should be done as early in the process as feasible and prior to, or concurrently with, notification to the Respondent.2. Throughout the proceeding, additional relevant records and items that are identified should be similarly preserved.3. Individuals involved in a Research Misconduct proceeding are expected to fully participate and cooperate in good faith. Obstruction of any aspect of the proceeding, including intentionally withholding or destroying evidence, may itself constitute evidence of Research Misconduct.4. If data collection methodology and/or information provided in the Privacy Certificate changes as a result of IRB requirements, a revised Privacy Certificate must be provided to the NIJ and IRB prior to the commencement of research.5. Records that contain non-disclosable information directly traceable to a particular person may not be stored in or introduced into an electronic retrieval system.These steps are designed to preserve the integrity of the records and ensure that they are available for review during any misconduct proceedings.

query: Which specific body fluids secretions and excretions are included in the application of Standard Precautions as outlined in the policy
response: Standard Precautions, as outlined in the policy, are designed to reduce the risk of transmission of microorganisms from both recognized and unrecognized sources of infection in healthcare facilities. These precautions apply to all patients, regardless of their diagnosis or presumed infection status. Specifically, they are applied to blood, all body fluids, secretions, and excretions, with the exception of sweat and tears. They also apply to non-intact skin and mucous membranes. This means that any body fluids, secretions, or excretions that are not sweat or tears are included in the application of Standard Precautions.

query: According to the hospitals policy what are the guidelines for initial ventilatory support for pediatric patients receiving ECMO
response: According to the hospital's policy, the guidelines for initial ventilatory support for pediatric patients receiving ECMO are as follows:1. Evaluate the airway and provide management according to the CCTT Neonatal and Pediatric Airway Management protocols in consultation with the Mobile ECMO team and the Medical Control Physician (MCP).2. Provide ventilatory support using the following guidelines for initial management, with adjustment based on discussion with the MCP:   - For neonatal patients:     - Ventilation Mode: Pressure Control/Synchronized Intermittent Mandatory (PC/SIMV)     - Peak Inspiratory Pressure (PIP): 25cm H2O     - Positive End Expiratory Pressure (PEEP): 5cm H2O     - Rate: 12 – 15 breaths per minute (bpm)     - Inspiratory Time (I-time): 0.6 – 0.8 seconds     - FiO2: 0.4 - 0.6   - For pediatric patients:     - Peak Inspiratory Pressures (PIP): < 35 cm H2O     - Positive End Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) levels: 5 – 10 cm H2O     - Tidal Volume (VT): < 8 mL/kgPlease note that the ventilator strategy is generally aimed at achieving lung rest while preserving lung volume. Always consult with the MCP for specific patient needs and adjustments.

query: How should the machine be cleaned following each use according to the hospital policy
response: Based on the sources provided, the machine should be cleaned after each use according to the following steps:1. The dialysis machine should be rinsed between patient use.2. The machine should be spot cleaned as necessary during treatment by a dialysis nurse or tech.3. After treatment, the machine should be externally cleaned and disinfected with a hospital-approved disinfectant.4. At the end of the day, the machine should be heat disinfected via an internal mechanism.5. Once a week, the machine should be internally cleaned with bleach.6. All reusable non-critical dialysis equipment should be cleaned with a hospital-approved disinfectant between uses on different patients.7. Each patient should have their own blood pressure cuff, which should be cleaned after use and allowed to dry before storage.8. Conductivity meters should be cleaned and disinfected after each use with Oxivir TB wipe.9. Thermometers should be dedicated to a treatment space and cleaned and disinfected after completion of treatment.10. External venous pressure transducer filters/protectors should be used for each patient treatment to prevent blood contamination of the dialysis machines' pressure monitors. These filters should be disposable and changed between patients.11. All fluid should be discarded and all surfaces and containers associated with the prime waste, including buckets attached to the machines, should be disposed of after use.12. Peritoneal dialysis equipment should be cleaned with a hospital-approved disinfectant after use by Dialysis Unit staff.

query: How should a nurse perform a vigorous mechanical scrub to the needleless connector with alcohol pad
response: To perform a vigorous mechanical scrub to the needleless connector with an alcohol pad, follow these steps:1. Ensure the area is clean and you have performed hand hygiene.2. Open an alcohol pad, touching only one corner to avoid contamination.3. Hold the needleless connector and perform a vigorous mechanical scrub with the alcohol pad for a minimum of 15 seconds. Make sure to scrub the entire surface of the connector.4. Allow the alcohol to dry completely before proceeding. This is crucial as it allows the alcohol to effectively disinfect the connector.5. If you need to perform the scrub again, for instance, before reconnecting to an infusion, use a new alcohol pad and repeat the process.

query: Who is responsible for approving the Training and Education Requirement Policy according to the document
response: The approval of the Training and Education Requirement Policy is a multi-step process involving several roles, as detailed in the sources provided.The initial review and approval of the document are the responsibility of the Document Owner, who ensures the content is relevant and up-to-date based on regulations, accreditation standards, current evidence, and related document attachments and reference tools. The Document Owner then sends the document for further review and approval to subject matter experts, stakeholders, and the Department Contact.Following this, the Department Contact receives the reviewed document and ensures approval at the department level, either by a Policy and Procedure Committee or directly by the Department Manager, depending on the specific policies and procedures of the organization.Once approved at the department level, the Policy Program Manager is notified, who then submits the document to the Policy Steering Committee (PSC) for review and approval. The PSC reviews and approves the document, education plan, and summary of changes, ensuring that the review process included necessary committees and stakeholders. The PSC Co-chairs or designee provide final sign-off on the document to be entered into the Document Management System (DMS).Finally, the Policy Program Manager publishes the document in the DMS, granting access to all end-users, and communicates the published document to the Department Contact. The Department Contact then confirms education completion and executes the communication strategy of document changes and the published document.In summary, the approval of the Training and Education Requirement Policy involves several roles, including the Document Owner, subject matter experts, stakeholders, Department Contact, Department Manager (if applicable), Policy Program Manager, and the Policy Steering Committee. The final approval is provided by the PSC Co-chairs or designee before the document is published and made accessible to all end-users.

query: Under what circumstances should CPAP therapy be initiated during a diagnostic study for a splitnight study
response: CPAP therapy during a diagnostic study for a split-night study should be initiated under the following circumstances:1. A minimum of 2 hours of diagnostic PSG (Polysomnography) has been conducted with an AHI (Apnea-Hypopnea Index) of at least 30.2. An AHI greater than 20 with documented symptoms of excessive daytime sleepiness, impaired cognition, mood disorders, insomnia, documented hypertension, ischemic heart disease, or history of stroke.3. Split night may be considered at an AHI of 15-40 based on clinical judgment.4. CPAP could be initiated during the diagnostic PSG by the technician as an emergency measure when multiple apneas leading to severe oxygen desaturation (below 70%) and/or prolonged apneas (more than 60 seconds) are observed.5. There must be at least 3 hours remaining study time for the CPAP titration.The CPAP pressure should be started at 5cw and titrated upward by 1cw to eliminate obstruction. Pressure should be increased slowly with a minimum of 5 minutes between 1cw increases. The optimal titration is where all obstructive events and snoring are resolved. Acceptable titration is where the obstructive RDI is < 5/hour.If a mask leak occurs, the tech should first fix the leakage before raising the pressure. Once the mask leak has been fixed, decrease the pressure to the last setting where mouth breathing and/or mask leakage was not present, and then re-titrate as indicated.If the patient takes a break from wearing the mask, do not decrease the CPAP pressure on attempted return to sleep unless the patient remains awake for 15 minutes or the patient specifically requests that the pressure be lowered.The use of bi-level positive airway pressure may be indicated if the patient is unable to tolerate CPAP secondary to persistent mouth breathing despite use of a full-face mask/chin strap, inability to exhale against higher expiratory pressures, or frequent central apneas.

query: What are the recommended sizes for postpyloric feeding tubes and when should a 10 Fr 43 in feeding tube be considered
response: The recommended sizes for postpyloric feeding tubes vary based on the patient's weight. For patients weighing 5 kg or less, a 6 Fr 22 in non-weighted feeding tube with a stylet is recommended. For patients weighing more than 5 kg, an 8 Fr 36-43 in non-weighted feeding tube with a stylet is suggested. A 10 Fr 43 in feeding tube can be considered for patients who are older than 12 years of age. The appropriate size of the nasal tube retaining system should be determined based on the feeding tube size. For instance, the Pediatric Pro Range™ comes in two sizes, 5F-6F and 8F-10F, to accommodate nasal tubes of the same size. It's also important to note that post-pyloric feedings are typically given continuously over a majority of the hours per day. If a patient is discharged with a post-pyloric tube, it's usually because they have improved with inpatient post-pyloric feedings or they continue to have severe illness that prompted the original placement of the post-pyloric tube. However, replacement of dislodged post-pyloric tubes typically does not occur at home or in most local Emergency Departments. The patient would likely need to present to a specialized medical facility to replace the tube via fluoroscopy.

query: How long do Multiple Wakefulness Tests MWT trials typically last and under what circumstances may a 20minute trial be ordered
response: Multiple Wakefulness Tests (MWTs) typically consist of four trials that are performed at two-hour intervals. Each trial usually lasts 40 minutes. However, the staff physician may order 20-minute trials under certain circumstances, such as for Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) requirements. The first trial begins about one and a half to three hours after the patient's usual wake-up time. Between trials, the patient is kept out of bed and is visually monitored to ensure that no napping occurs. The MWT is recorded with standard polysomnography and the mean sleep latency is determined across four trials. The need to perform a PSG prior to MWT is determined by the staff physician based on clinical circumstances.

query: What are the guidelines for administration of medication by the enteral tube route as mentioned in the document
response: The guidelines for administering medication by the enteral tube route include:1. Medications can be administered via nasogastric, orogastric, gastrostomy, naso, post-pyloric (jejunal or duodenal), and gastro-jejunal tubes.2. Do not use parenteral (IV) syringes for enteral medications. Always use a new syringe for flushing after medication administration.3. Administer medications in a consistent manner to maintain therapeutic levels.4. Crush and dissolve tablets before administration. However, some medications cannot be crushed or administered via an enteral tube due to potential complications like precipitation, clogging, or degrading the tube.5. Some specific medications like Clarithromycin, Ciprofloxacin, Kayexalate (except through a gastric tube), Magnesium Oxide, Metamucil, Sucralfate, and Thorazine oral concentrate should not be administered through an enteral tube.6. Do not crush sustained release, controlled release, sublingual, buccal, enteric coated, or chewable medications for enteral tube administration, except for multivitamins and chewable aspirin if crushed and dissolved in water.7. Administer medications separately by the enteral tube route rather than in combination.8. Flush the enteral tube well with water between each medication.9. If a patient vomits a medication, consult with the prescriber to determine if the dose needs to be repeated.10. For post-pyloric tube administration, only liquid medications should be used. If no liquid preparation is available, dissolve the medication in liquid with no visible particles prior to administration.11. Dilute post-pyloric liquid medications with an equal volume of sterile water at a minimum. This practice can be modified for fluid-sensitive patients.12. Limit medication administration via post-pyloric tube due to concerns for altered absorption and potential alteration in drug efficacy.13. If a patient is stable and tolerating medications on their home regimen, and the tube is not clogging, their home routine may be continued when inpatient.Always consult with the pharmacy or prescriber for additional information or options.

query: What specific information should the PACU nurse provide to the unit nurse before transfer using the IPASS report tool
response: The PACU nurse should provide the following specific information to the unit nurse before transfer using the IPASS report tool:1. Patient's weight and allergies.2. Medications given during the procedure.3. Any tubes or drains placed, and details about them.4. Information about heparin locks and central venous lines, including time of last flush and heparin concentration.5. Availability of blood products.6. Special needs of the patient and personal belongings.7. Details about the surgical procedure and dressing applied.8. Notify the unit of special equipment and/or patient considerations.9. Provide an estimated time of arrival.10. Complete a discharge summary before transfer to the inpatient unit.Upon arrival to the floor, the nurse-to-nurse report includes identifying the patient, assessing the patient, checking the PCA or epidural/regional catheter settings, assessing the IV site, and viewing the operative site. The receiving nurse then follows the Patient Care Manual: Patient Admission policy.

query: What are the specific postboil water instructions that hospitals need to follow during a water supply problem
response: During a water supply problem in a hospital, the following steps should be taken:1. Report the issue to your supervisor immediately.2. Contact the appropriate authority, such as the MEHC Director, Facility Manager, or Whelan Associates, to report your findings. They will assess the nature and scope of the water supply problem.4. Be aware that a water supply problem may trigger device failures or disruptions, such as fire suppression systems, temperature-controlled air systems, drinking fountains, sinks, and toilets.5. The on-site directors and/or managers will oversee the distribution of water as needed.However, the sources do not provide specific postboil water instructions for hospitals during a water supply problem.

query: What are the specific conditions that require contacting the Medical Control Physician before transport
response: The specific conditions that require contacting the Medical Control Physician before transport, as per the provided sources, are:1. Patients with conditions that require the assistance of a qualified physician for airway management, or for whom intubation in the operating room should be considered.2. Patients who cannot be intubated by the transport team members or a qualified physician from the referring facility.3.
