query: What are the responsibilities of the Registered Nurses RNs working in the 10 Northwest inpatient surgical unit
response: The Registered Nurses (RNs) working in the 10 Northwest (10NW) inpatient surgical unit are responsible for a variety of tasks related to patient care. Their primary duties include assessing patients, planning care, monitoring patient progress, providing physical care, managing medications and pain, educating patients and families, planning for discharge, and continuously evaluating the care provided.RNs in this unit work closely with an interdisciplinary team that includes physicians, pharmacists, social workers, child life specialists, nutrition support staff, physical therapists, nurse practitioners, and pastoral care to ensure all patient needs are met. They coordinate care for surgical and orthopedic patients of all ages, and their shifts can be either 8 or 12 hours long to provide maximum support during peak patient flow times.The staffing plan is arranged to accommodate specific patient populations, with more experienced RNs available as clinical resources for less experienced nurses. A Charge Nurse, who is an RN specifically trained for the role, is assigned to each shift to manage daily unit operations and serve as a clinical resource.In addition to direct patient care, some RNs participate in leadership roles, contributing to the development, implementation, and evaluation of unit goals. Case Managers, who are also RNs, support discharge planning and utilization review processes.

query: How should the nursing staff respond if there is a suspected or confirmed contamination of water within the water supply system at North Dartmouth
response: In the event of a suspected or confirmed contamination of water within the water supply system at North Dartmouth, the nursing staff should take the following steps:1. Report the water supply problem to their supervisor immediately.2. Perform a preliminary evaluation to describe the type and scope of the water supply problem.3. Contact Whelan Associates (Bill Whelan: 508-330-4445) to report the findings. Whelan Associates, along with the North Dartmouth Manager (#8502), will assess the nature and scope of the water supply problem.4. If the fire suppression system is impacted by the contamination, determine the need for evacuation or an approved fire watch based on the length of time the system is anticipated to be out of service. Whelan Associates or their designee coordinates fire watch activities with the North Dartmouth Fire Department (0-911) and the North Dartmouth Manager.5. The North Dartmouth Manager (#8502) will oversee the distribution of water as needed.6. Infection Prevention and Control On Call (pager #2058, Page operator 617-355-6363) should also be notified.7. If necessary, contact a vendor for alternate water supply delivery.

query: What are the specific situations that require gown and glove use for contact with patients known to be colonized with a MDRO
response: The use of gowns and gloves for contact with patients known to be colonized with a Multidrug-Resistant Organism (MDRO) is primarily dependent on the setting of care.1. In high-risk settings such as hospitals, emergency departments, and ambulatory settings that perform invasive procedures, Contact Precautions should be used. This includes the use of gowns and gloves when in contact with the patient.2. In low-risk ambulatory settings like primary care, pre-op clinics, and specialty clinics, Standard Precautions are sufficient. However, gown and glove use is required for contact with pressure ulcers, draining wounds, uncontrolled secretions, stool incontinence, and ostomy bags.3. For patients with Aerosol Generating Procedures (AGP), the appropriate AGP sign should be posted with the Contact Precautions sign, and a gown and gloves should be worn for transport.4. Parents and visitors do not need to wear gowns and gloves but should practice diligent hand hygiene.5. In surgical settings, sterile gowns and gloves should be used following the Surgical Hand Scrub policy, and the scrub person should maintain the sterile boundaries of the surgical gown for self and all personnel in the sterile field.6. Gloves should be changed during invasive surgical procedures when suspected or actual contamination occurs.

query: What supplies are needed for the central venous catheter CVC needleless connector procedure

query: What are the types of evidencebased psychotherapies that OPS clinicians provide and in what delivery options are they available
response: The Outpatient Psychiatry Service (OPS) offers evidence-based psychotherapies, which include Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and Parent-Child Interaction Therapy (PCIT). These therapies are provided in both individual and group settings. OPS clinicians also offer psychopharmacology as part of their treatment recommendations. These services are delivered in-person as well as virtually, depending on the agreement with patients and families. The OPS also provides collaborative behavioral health care services with other care providers, and once a patient has been stabilized, they may work with behavioral health clinicians or primary care practitioners in the community to assume the patient's care. (Source 1)

query: How soon should an adverse or near miss event be reported and through what channels should it be reported according to the hospitals policy
response: An adverse or near miss event should be reported within 24 hours of becoming aware of the event. It should be reported to a supervisor or other clinical/administrative leaders, as well as through the hospital's internal web-based Safety Event Reports System (SERS). This applies to any hospital employee, volunteer, Medical Staff member, or House Staff member. If staff are uncertain whether an event is a reportable adverse or near miss event, they should err on the side of reporting. In the case of an adverse drug event, it should be reported to the prescriber immediately (or the attending physician if the prescriber is not available), in addition to submitting a SERS within 24 hours. The criteria for reporting an event through SERS include any occurrence of an adverse event, any near miss event, an event or situation that places a patient at increased risk of harm, or unplanned significant change in medical or surgical management not related to the patient's underlying condition.

query: What should the clinical team do if a patient or family objects to the use of blood or blood products for religious or other reasons
response: If a patient or family objects to the use of blood or blood products for religious or other reasons, the clinical team should first discuss the various blood alternatives that may be acceptable to the patient or family. If there continue to be concerns and it is necessary to provide blood or blood products, the team may need to consider contacting a hospital attorney to consider legal action to obtain authorization. It's important to note that all blood and blood products used from a donor are tested by the hospital. However, blood provided by the patient in advance of their own procedure is not tested for transmissible diseases if it is donated at the hospital. In an effort to avoid blood product usage and respect the patient's wishes, the clinical team should consider other options such as conventional and zero balance ultrafiltration to control the electrolytes and lactate level in the patient's circulating blood volume. If a transfusion reaction is suspected, the Blood Bank must be notified immediately for advice on next steps.

query: Under what circumstances can the team composition be altered according to the hospital policy

query: How is Earned Time deducted for Exempt Employees on Observed Holidays occurring on weekdays
response: For exempt employees at BCH, 8 hours of Earned Time (ET) are deducted for any observed holiday occurring on a weekday, as long as the employee is full-time (1.0 FTE). For part-time exempt employees with less than 1.0 FTE, ET is deducted on a pro rata daily basis for observed holidays on weekdays. No ET is deducted if the observed holiday falls on a Saturday or Sunday, unless the employee is regularly scheduled to work on those days. If exempt employees work on an observed holiday, they are not eligible for holiday pay, and their base salary remains the same. Exempt employees must use ET for BCH-recognized holidays and any other absences for which they are normally scheduled to work. ET is deducted in 1-hour increments for exempt employees for full and partial day absences.

query: What is the process for suggesting a voting action at a convened IRB meeting
response: The process for suggesting a voting action at a convened IRB meeting involves the following steps:1. A full discussion of the issue at hand is held at the convened IRB meeting.2. The primary and secondary reviewers assigned to the issue suggest a voting action.3. The IRB Chair calls for a committee vote on the suggested action.4. The Chair may continue the discussion until a consensus is reached, but a vote can be called at any time.The voting actions that can be taken include accepting the event, requesting additional information, or suspending recruitment or the entire protocol as necessary. The IRB will also vote on whether the event meets the criteria for reporting. This process is applicable to various issues discussed at the meeting, including unanticipated events and amendments/revisions that do not meet the criteria for expedited review.

query: What are the annual requirements for a Registered Nurse RN to maintain compliance with hospital policies and the Massachusetts Nurse Practice Act
response: Based on the retrieved sources, the annual requirements for a Registered Nurse (RN) to maintain compliance with hospital policies and the Massachusetts Nurse Practice Act include:1. Holding a current Massachusetts nursing license.2. Maintaining a current Basic Life Support (BLS) certification.3. Completing hospital and unit orientation.4. Meeting annual hospital and unit competencies.5. Completing continuing education in compliance with the Massachusetts Nurse Practice Act.6. Finishing assigned Net Learning requirements.Additional requirements may include annual fire safety, risk management, and hazardous materials training, and in some cases, Pediatric Advanced Life Support (PALS) or Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) certification. Annual self-evaluation and peer review may also be necessary.

query: How should a nurse initiate the use of a patient handling device according to the hospital policy
response: Based on the most relevant source (source 1), here's how a nurse should initiate the use of a patient handling device according to hospital policy:1. Adjust the bed to the correct height. This should be at waist level when providing care and hip level when mobilizing a patient out of bed.2. Maintain a wide, stable base with your feet, about shoulder width apart.3. Tighten your stomach muscles immediately before and during the patient handling activity. Keep your back as straight as possible.4. Keep the patient (and/or device being used) as close to yourself as possible. Avoid overreaching and any unnecessary twisting in the spine.5. Assess the patient's mobility needs and use proper patient handling equipment and techniques best suited for patient needs.6. Assess the space needed within the room to safely mobilize the patient.7. Arrange the patient room prior to initiating patient handling activity.8. If using a ceiling or floor lift, be certain to use the correct sling for the type of safe patient handling activity being performed.9. For lateral transfers, use appropriate equipment based on the patient's weight. For patients up to 45 kg / 100 lbs, use a slide board, rollboard or slide sheet. For patients weighing more than 45 kg / 100 lbs, use air-assisted technology, portable lift or ceiling lift.

query: According to the Holidays and Holiday Pay Policy what is the holiday premium pay for time worked by a NonExempt or Exempt Plus Employee on an Observed Holiday
response: According to the Holidays and Holiday Pay Policy, Non-Exempt Employees are eligible for Holiday Pay for all time worked on an Observed Holiday. Holiday Pay is paid at a rate of one-and-a-half times the Non-Exempt Employee's base hourly rate. Exempt Plus Employees are eligible for Holiday Pay as a premium when working a shift on an Observed Holiday. Holiday Pay is paid for all hours in the shift at 50% of the Employee's Base Hourly Rate Equivalent and is in addition to the Employee's regular base salary. Holiday Pay is paid to eligible employees who work on the actual holiday (January 1, June 19, July 4, or December 25), not the observed holiday if it falls on a weekend.

query: In cases of suspected child abuse who should the nurses contact according to the hospital policy
response: In cases of suspected child abuse, nurses should contact the Massachusetts Department of Children and Families (DCF) according to the hospital policy and Massachusetts General Laws, Ch. 119, Section 51 A. This applies when a nurse, in their professional capacity, has reasonable cause to believe that a child under the age of 18 is suffering from physical or emotional injury due to abuse or neglect. If the patient is unable to answer the screening question and additional risk indicators are apparent, the nurse should contact Social Work. In addition, the hospital's Child Protection Team (CPT) is available 24/7 for consultation. The nurse can contact them if they suspect child maltreatment. The hospital also encourages staff to report any suspicions to their team/unit/program social worker and the appropriate supervisor for their department.

query: Which types of catheters are included in the category of Dialysis and Apheresis Catheters once converted
response: The types of catheters included in the category of Dialysis and Apheresis Catheters, once converted, are:1. Dialysis Catheters: These are a type of Central Venous Catheters (CVCs) used for long-term intravenous access. They are inserted into the central venous system.2. Apheresis Catheters: These are also a type of CVCs. There are two types of Apheresis Catheters - a non-tunneled subclavian or internal jugular catheter, also called a temporary central venous line, and a tunneled subclavian or internal jugular catheter, also called a permanent central venous line. Apheresis catheters are made of a firm material to allow them to function at the high flow rates necessary for adequate Apheresis treatments.

query: What are the steps to be followed for preparing the return of blood during the LDL Apheresis procedure as outlined in the document
response: The steps to prepare for the return of blood during the LDL Apheresis procedure are not directly outlined in the provided sources. However, based on the related information, here are some general steps that might be applicable:1. Confirm that the patient has an active extended consent for transfusion of blood products.2. Check if the patient requires pre-medication. If so, ensure there are prescriber orders in the electronic medical record for medications and pre-medicate the patient prior to transfusion.3. Visually inspect the blood for any abnormalities such as a cloudy appearance, obvious clots, or hemolysis (pink plasma). Notify the blood bank with any concerns.4. Prepare the blood and perform the transfusion as specified in the patient care manual for Transfusion of Blood Products.5. Ensure that the blood enters the dialysis circuit pre-dialyzer. Throughout the course of the transfusion, dialysate flow must be on.6. The volume of blood to be infused is given over a time period that allows ultrafiltration of an equivalent volume. This means that the transfusion(s) may be administered rapidly during dialysis due to the fluid volume of the cells being removed at the same time as infusion.7. Remain with the patient for the first 5 minutes of the transfusion. Document and monitor the transfusion as per the Patient Care Manual: Transfusion of Blood Products.8. Obtain and document vital signs 15 minutes after the transfusion begins, every 30 minutes from the initiation of the transfusion, and upon completion of the transfusion.9. Monitor the dialysis patient for any suspected transfusion reactions and/or acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (HRT). Follow the procedure for reactions as outlined in the Patient Care Manual: Transfusion of Blood Products. Note: Report any suspected reactions to the Blood Bank and physician immediately.Please consult with a healthcare professional or refer to the specific policy-chat API document for the most accurate information.

query: What is the role of a Communications Specialist in relation to the Transport Team and other medical personnel involved in transport
response: The role of a Communications Specialist in relation to the Transport Team and other medical personnel involved in transport is primarily that of a centralized communicator. The Communications Specialist is the single point of contact who receives and relays information to and from the Transport Team, Medical Control Physician, and other medical personnel involved in the transport. This is to maintain continuity and accuracy in dispatching transport calls.The Communications Specialist who initiates a transport request is responsible for communicating with the team throughout the transport. If another Communications Specialist receives a call related to the transport, they should put the caller on hold until the Communications Specialist handling the transport is available. All calls should be made through a dedicated transport phone line to ensure proper recording and free use of the line.In situations where the response time of the Critical Care Transport Team is inadequate, the Communications Specialist is responsible for making other arrangements for transport on behalf of the referring physician. This could include coordinating with other critical care teams or air transport services.Therefore, the Communications Specialist plays a crucial role in ensuring smooth communication and coordination among all parties involved in a patient's transport.

query: When should the Senior Leadership Communication Center SCLC be notified of a formal HICS activation
response: The Senior Leadership Communication Center (SCLC) should be notified of a formal HICS activation by the Administrator on Duty (AOD) or their designee. This notification is a part of the standard procedure for any formal HICS activation. The AOD or their designee will also provide daily SCLC SBAR emails for the duration of the activation. In cases where the activation involves time-sensitive or life safety concerns, direct face-to-face or phone notification will be made to the President & CEO by the AOD or their designee.

query: What are the essential elements for continuous cardiorespiratory monitoring during cardioversion defibrillation and pacing procedures
response: The essential elements for continuous cardiorespiratory monitoring during cardioversion defibrillation and pacing procedures include:1. Assessing the patient's ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) and performing airway management according to the CCTT Airway Management protocol. Oxygen therapy or positive-pressure ventilations with 100% oxygen should be initiated according to the CCTT Respiratory Distress/Failure protocol. If the patient is pulseless, chest compressions should be initiated according to the current American Heart Association Basic Life Support guidelines.2. Obtaining vascular access but not delaying electrical therapy.3. Performing synchronized cardioversion or defibrillation as indicated using the energy levels according to the current American Heart Association Pediatric Advanced Life Support guidelines.4. Applying the appropriate-sized paddles/pads in the standard sterno-apical configuration or using the anterior-posterior technique.5. Using conductive gel or pre-gelled defibrillation pads.6. For patients who are responsive, considering providing sedation according to the CCTT Analgesia and Sedation protocol.7. Following cardioversion, reassessing the cardiac rhythm. Following defibrillation, resuming chest compressions immediately for approximately two minutes until reassessing cardiac rhythm and pulse.8. Documenting a recording of the ECG before and after each event.9. Maintaining patient and team member safety during energy delivery.10. Following the American Heart Association Pediatric or Adult Advanced Life Support algorithms for further care.Additionally, continuous EKG monitoring is required for cardioversion. For patients with an Automatic Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator (AICD), it's important to avoid placing the defibrillator paddles/pads over the AICD device.

query: What equipment is typically used for transferring blood from the pump circuit to the cell saver
response: The equipment typically used for transferring blood from the pump circuit to the cell saver includes a stopcock, a blood spike pin adapter, and a male-male line. This process is often facilitated by the perfusionist, who ensures the aseptic assembly and priming of the cell saver circuit before use. The filtered blood from the bag is directed to the MUF (Modified Ultrafiltration) circuit by way of a line from the stopcock of the quick prime line and returned to the blood bag by way of the MUF return line to a dispensing pin in the other port of the blood bag. This procedure is done to correct issues with bank blood before transfusion to the pump circuit.

query: Who is responsible for managing the response to a suspicious package or bomb threat at North Dartmouth according to the hospital policy

query: How do you bleed air from the arterial line during the rinse process and what should you do when the rinse mode is complete

query: What parameters should be monitored during and after suctioning an artificial airway
response: During and after suctioning an artificial airway, the following parameters should be monitored:1. ECG, respiratory rate, blood pressure, SpO2 (oxygen saturation), and CO2 (carbon dioxide) levels should be continuously monitored.2. The patient's temperature should be continuously monitored using either a rectal probe or skin electrode, with high and low temperature alarm limits set and active.3. The patient's vital signs should be monitored throughout the procedure.4. If the patient is receiving neuromuscular blockade, the level of chemical paralysis should be assessed daily using train-of-four monitoring or a "holiday" period off paralytics, per the Neuromuscular Blockade policy.5. The level of suction should be confirmed to be appropriate for the age of the patient, with vacuum pressure not to exceed -80 mm Hg for neonates, -80 to -100 mm Hg for pediatric patients and -120 mmHg for adult patients.6. The depth of suction should not be more than 1 cm beyond the end of the artificial airway to prevent irritation/trauma to the trachea and carina, unless a different depth of suction is specified by the prescriber in a written order.7. Each pass of the suction catheter should not exceed 5 to 10 seconds to decrease the potential for oxygen depletion.8. Post-procedure hyper-oxygenation should be provided when indicated.9. Pre-and post-treatment assessments should be provided including SpO2, RR (respiratory rate), FO (fraction of inspired oxygen) requirement, breath sounds, and respiratory effort. The patient's tolerance to the treatment should be determined and changes to the plan should be recommended as needed.The sources provided mainly focus on the procedure of suctioning an artificial airway and the importance of monitoring vital signs and oxygen saturation levels during the procedure. Source 1 and 2 provide the most relevant information regarding the parameters that should be monitored during and after suctioning an artificial airway.

query: When is it necessary for the Primary Provider to have a discussion with the patient andor the parentguardian prior to the start of a recommended procedure intervention or treatment
response: The primary provider should have a discussion with the patient and/or the parent/guardian prior to the start of a recommended procedure, intervention, or treatment, except in cases of medical emergencies. This discussion is part of the informed consent process, which aims to ensure that the patient and/or the parent/guardian understand the benefits, risks, and alternatives involved in the procedure. The conversation should be meaningful, unhurried, and actively involve the patient and/or the parent/guardian in the decision-making process. The primary provider or a provider within the same department should have an oral discussion with the patient and/or the parent/guardian regarding the procedure. The primary provider must sign the consent form prior to the start of the procedure, confirming that they have discussed the risks, benefits, and alternatives with the patient and/or the parent/guardian. In cases where another provider has obtained consent, the primary provider should still meet with the patient and/or parent/guardian to verify they understand the risks and benefits before signing the form.

query: How are events classified and recorded in the Safety Event Reporting System SERS at Boston Childrens Hospital
response: At Boston Children's Hospital (BCH), events are classified and recorded in the Safety Event Reporting System (SERS), an electronic system that allows any staff member to report near misses, errors, or other adverse events. Staff members are encouraged to report events within 24 hours of recognition.The events are assigned a level of severity from 0 to 5 by the person completing the report, with 0 indicating a near miss and 5 indicating a patient death. An email alert is sent to specific hospital authorities for all reported events.The Unit Nurse Manager/Clinical Coordinator reviews all SERS reports and assigns a final level of severity. For events designated as Level 3, 4, or 5, the Nurse Manager ensures adequate review, evaluation, and intervention if required. The Nurse Manager also reviews all SERS reports monthly at the Multidisciplinary Meeting.In addition, if it is determined that a cellular therapy product has resulted in an adverse event or reaction, the event and results of the investigation are reported to the donor's and recipient's physician(s), other facilities participating in the manufacturing of the cellular therapy product, registries, and governmental agencies as required by applicable laws and regulations.This summary is based on the information provided in the sources, with source 1 being the most relevant. The other sources provided information about different institutions or different types of events, so they were less relevant to the query.

query: What are the key steps for verifying the prescribers order for enteral feeding schedule type volume and duration
response: Based on the sources provided, here are the key steps for verifying the prescriber's order for enteral feeding schedule type volume and duration:1. Verify the feeding order route, type, volume, and duration. Double-check for any allergy or formula intolerance (Source 1).2. The type of feeding can be breast milk, donor human milk, or formula. The choice depends on availability and the patient's eligibility (Source 2).3. For the feeding schedule, typically, gastric feeding should be initiated as a bolus over 15-30 minutes every 3 hours. However, continuous feedings are also acceptable depending on the patient's condition (Source 2).4. The volume and duration of feeding depend on the patient's weight. Guidelines for initiation and advancement of enteral feeding volumes are listed in Source 2.5. Full feeding volume is 150 mL/kg/day. Target energy intake is 110-130 kcal/kg/day, and target protein intake is 4.0 to 4.5 g/kg for infants < 1000 g, and 3.5 to 4.0 g/kg for infants 1000 to 1500 g (Source 2).6. Use an enteral feeding pump for patients who cannot tolerate gravity feeds administered over 20 to 30 minutes (Source 5).7. Always ensure oxygen and suction equipment are available at the patient's bedside at all times (Source 5).

query: What procedures and services are performed in CAIR during outpatient visits
response: During outpatient visits to the Center for Advanced Intestinal Rehabilitation (CAIR), various procedures and services are performed. These include the removal and replacement of gastrostomy tubes, removal of sutures, cauterization of granulation tissue with silver nitrate, and blood sampling from port-a-catheters, PICC lines, and/or broviac central venous catheters (CVCs). Additionally, sterile CVC dressing and cap changes are conducted.Outpatient services also involve phone triage for management of hydration status, G-tube care, ostomy care, feeding intolerance, skin and wound care, infection control, review of lab results and diagnostic studies, medication management, prescription refills, and overall care coordination related to intestinal failure.Patients are routinely seen for follow-up visits to support intestinal rehabilitation and to screen for and treat complications of intestinal failure. Sick visits are also accommodated as needed. These visits involve collaboration among several disciplines, including social work, nutrition, gastroenterology, surgery, pharmacy, nursing, behavioral psychology, and speech language pathology.It's important to note that more complex procedures requiring anesthesia or sedation services may be performed at specific locations, and these are typically limited to ASA 1, ASA 2, and sometimes ASA 3 patients (pending review and approval by the designated attending anesthesiologist). However, cardiovascular and neurosurgical procedures, surgeries with significant blood loss requiring transfusion, and procedures requiring time in an Intensive Care Unit are typically not performed in an outpatient setting.Lastly, medication reconciliation is a key part of outpatient care, with documentation of each patient's current medications, OTC products, and supplements updated frequently in the electronic medical record.

query: When should direct communication between the attending medical staff member and consultant be initiated for a patient with critical issues
response: Direct communication between the attending medical staff member and consultant should be initiated for a patient with critical issues as soon as possible. The attending medical staff member should clearly convey the urgency of the consult to the consultant. If the consult is considered emergent, the attending medical staff member or their designee should contact the consultant directly to communicate the request for an immediate evaluation. For all other issues, both the attending medical staff member and consultant should ensure that there is bidirectional communication based on the request for consultation and any findings. The attending medical staff member remains responsible for communication with the patient and/or the parent/guardian, and may include the consultant if they are providing recommendations that will be incorporated into the plan of care. In cases where the patient is being transferred to the consultant's service, direct verbal communication between the transferring and receiving attending must occur, particularly for patients transferred into the ICUs.

query: How should nurses document specific Safe Lifting Transferring and Moving Patients and Equipment information according to the Patient Care Manual

query: What are the recommended administration methods for enteral feedings by gravity
response: The recommended administration methods for enteral feedings by gravity are:1. Administer enteral feedings through an enteral syringe feeding tubing or through an enteral feeding bag attached directly to the feeding tube.2. Use a gravity administration set (e.g., 1000 mL, 500 mL or bottle) or an appropriate size syringe with the plunger removed to administer enteral feedings by gravity.3. Administer gravity feedings into the stomach only by nasogastric, orogastric, or gastrostomy tube when the patient has inadequate oral intake.4. Ensure oxygen and suction equipment are available at the patient bedside at all times.It's also important to note that intravenous tubing should not be used for enteral feeds to prevent inadvertent administration of enteral feeding via the intravenous route. If a patient cannot tolerate gravity feeds administered over 20 to 30 minutes, or has reflux or vomiting, it may be necessary to use an enteral feeding pump and administer the feeding over a longer period.

query: How does the hospitals policy recommend handling the draft investigation report and what input is requested from the Respondent and Complainant
response: The hospital's policy recommends that the draft investigation report be shared with the Respondent and, if appropriate, the Complainant for review. The Respondent and Complainant are then expected to provide their written responses to the draft report. These responses will be considered and addressed by the panel and attached to the final Investigation report (source 1). The panel will conduct its review and incorporate the comments of the Respondent and Complainant in the report (source 2). Throughout the proceeding, the Respondent has an opportunity to present his/her case and to review and comment on draft reports generated by the Inquiry proceeding (source 4). The confidentiality and privacy of the Respondent and Complainant are protected, and disclosure of information is limited to those who have a need to know (source 5).

query: How should the nurse assess the functional mobility of a patient to determine the most appropriate method of mobilization
response: To assess the functional mobility of a patient and determine the most appropriate method of mobilization, a nurse should follow these steps:1. Evaluate the patient's functional mobility. This assessment helps determine the best method for moving, lifting, or transferring the patient.2. Consider the patient's needs, their ability to participate, the total lifting weight, the handling task (lifting, moving, repositioning), and the physical environment when planning a lift.3. Consider the safe patient handling equipment available to assist with the move, lift, or transfer. This equipment may include ceiling lifts, floor-based portable lifts (like a Hoyer Lift), air-assisted technology (such as a HoverMatt), lateral transfer devices (like slide boards or roll boards), or slide sheets (like Comfort Glide).4. Determine how many people will be needed to move the patient safely. A minimum of two people is usually required for out-of-bed activities.5. Determine if the patient will be able to participate in the mobilization process. If so, discuss how and coach the patient on what to expect.6. If necessary, rehearse the patient handling activity to ensure safety and comfort for both the patient and the caregivers.

query: What practice parameters do splitnight studies follow according to the AASM
response: Split-night studies, according to the sources provided, are performed to diagnose sleep apnea and determine effective Positive Airway Pressure (PAP) treatment. These studies follow the practice parameters set by the American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM). The diagnostic portion of the split-night sleep study should be performed according to the AASM Practice Parameters for the Indications for Polysomnography and Related Procedures. The application of electrodes, montages, filters, sensitivities, and scoring is performed according to the AASM Scoring Manual. However, the specific details of these practice parameters are not provided in the sources. It's recommended to refer to the AASM's official guidelines for comprehensive information.

query: What are the specific requirements for the sterile nitrile gloves used during the compounding of hazardous drugs as per the hospital policy
response: The specific requirements for the sterile nitrile gloves used during the compounding of hazardous drugs as per the hospital policy are:1. The gloves must be appropriately rated, specifically ASTM D6978-rated, which is the minimum requirement.2. The gloves must be disposable and changed immediately if they become contaminated.3. When handling hazardous medications or patient body fluids during administration, the gloves should be used for the duration and for the 48 hours post hazardous medication administration.4. For sterile compounding, a second pair of ASTM 6978-rated outer gloves must be sterile.5. The outer sterile gloves must be changed at least every 30 minutes or when grossly contaminated.These requirements ensure the safety of the healthcare workers and prevent the contamination of the hazardous drugs.

query: What are the different concentrations and volumes of Fentanyl and Midazolam infusions listed in the document
response: Based on the provided sources, I can give you the following information about the concentrations and volumes of Fentanyl and Midazolam infusions:1. For patients whose airway is not secured, Midazolam can be administered at a dose of 0.05 – 0.1 mg/kg IV with a maximum single dose of 2 mg. If needed, it can be repeated once at 0.05 mg/kg after 5 minutes, with a maximum total dose of 2 mg.2. For patients who are endotracheally intubated, Midazolam can be administered at a dose of 0.1 mg/kg IV with a maximum single dose of 4 mg. It can be repeated as needed at 0.05 – 0.1 mg/kg IV every 30 – 60 min.3. For pain management in patients whose airway is not secured, Fentanyl can be administered at a dose of 1 – 2 micrograms/kg IV with a maximum single dose of 100 micrograms. If needed, it can be repeated once at the same dose after 5 minutes.4. For patients who are endotracheally intubated, Fentanyl can be administered at a dose of 1 - 3 micrograms/kg IV with a maximum single dose of 100 micrograms. It can be repeated as needed every 15 -30 min.

query: What are the annual requirements for staff members in terms of hospital competencies and selfevaluation
response: Based on the sources provided, the annual requirements for staff members in terms of hospital competencies and self-evaluation can be summarized as follows:1. All staff members are required to complete annual hospital and unit competencies. These competencies are designed to ensure that staff members are up-to-date with the latest practices and standards in their respective fields.2. Staff members are expected to participate in continuing education programs to maintain and enhance their professional competence. This is in compliance with the Massachusetts Nurse Practice Act and other relevant professional standards.3. All staff members undergo an annual performance appraisal. This process includes an evaluation of their competencies, including age-specific care needs for nurses.4. Staff members are also required to complete assigned online learning modules (Net Learning) and annual mandatory reviews.5. In addition to these, staff members are introduced to age-specific care needs during orientation and are responsible for these competencies each year during their performance appraisals.6. In-services and continuing education programs are provided to maintain staff competency. These programs are offered both centrally and unit-based, and they meet educational needs identified from a variety of sources, including an annual staff education survey.7. For psychologists and social workers, individual weekly supervision is required of all new staff for the first six months of employment or until licensed.These requirements ensure that staff members are well-equipped to provide high-quality care to patients and their families.

query: When should a patient with a new murmur be referred to cardiology for further evaluation
response: A patient with a new murmur should be referred to cardiology for further evaluation. This is the standard procedure for any patient with a new murmur. However, if the murmur has already been documented as an "innocent murmur" by a cardiologist, then a referral to cardiology is not necessary. If the patient is under the age of 1 year with an innocent murmur documented by a pediatrician, they can proceed with their treatment as long as there are no cardiac symptoms, and clearance by a cardiologist is not required. If a cardiac finding such as a new murmur is discovered during the anesthesia pre-op evaluation and the patient is not followed by a cardiologist, the nursing practitioner should call the cardiology clinic charge nurse to request a pre-op cardiac evaluation. If the patient cannot be seen by a cardiologist prior to surgery, the nursing practitioner should notify the surgeon about the need to possibly reschedule the surgery.

query: What are the requirements for an advance practice provider APP to provide overnight medical care for Pediatric Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant HSCT patients

query: When should the Medical Control Physician be contacted according to the clinical protocol
response: The Medical Control Physician should be contacted in the following situations based on the provided sources:1. When transporting term or near-term infants with hypoxemic respiratory failure and clinical or echocardiographic evidence of pulmonary hypertension who are receiving iNO at the time of transport, to discuss the concentration of iNO to be used during transport.2. When transporting term or near-term infants with hypoxemic respiratory failure and clinical or echocardiographic evidence of pulmonary hypertension who are not receiving iNO at the time of transport, to discuss the initiation of iNO and the initial dose.3. If there are any changes needed in the iNO concentration during transport.4. In cases of pneumoperitoneum, coagulopathy with clinical bleeding, and persistent signs of shock following volume resuscitation and initiation of dopamine according to the CCTT Neonatal Shock protocol.5. In cases of persistent seizure activity despite administration of anti-convulsants per protocol, patients with hypersensitivity to anticonvulsants in the protocol, hyponatremia associated with seizures, focal neurologic abnormalities after cessation of seizure activity, and significant changes in neurologic exam during transport.6. Any deviation from practices outlined in the CCTT Patient Care Protocols requires discussion with the Medical Control Physician, including the rationale for deviation and alternative plan of care.

query: Who is responsible for notifying all departments and the Satellite AOC when there is an All Clear at North Dartmouth

This is done after receiving confirmation from the outside authority in charge that the incident has passed. The Satellite AOC then notifies the Administrator On Duty (AOD) of the "All Clear".

query: What licenses and certifications are required for an Advanced Practice Registered Nurse APRN in Massachusetts
response: To work as an Advanced Practice Registered Nurse (APRN) in Massachusetts, the following licenses and certifications are required based on the provided sources:1. Massachusetts Registered Nurse License: This is a fundamental requirement for all nursing professionals in Massachusetts.2. Massachusetts Nurse Practitioner License and National Certification: In addition to the RN license, an APRN must also have a specific license for nurse practitioners and a national certification in their area of specialty.3. Basic Life Support (BLS) Certification: This certification is required for all healthcare professionals involved in direct patient care, including APRNs.4. Other specific certifications may be required depending on the area of practice. For instance, Pediatric Advanced Life Support, Neonatal Resuscitation Program, Advanced Cardiac Life Support, and Emergency Vehicle Driver Training (EVDT) or equivalent may be required within the first year of hire.6. It includes central and department-based orientation during which APRs demonstrate competence and adhere to professional scope and standards of practice.

query: How is the primary reviewer of an unanticipated event expected to present the event and provide comments during the convened IRB meeting
response: The primary reviewer of an unanticipated event is expected to present the event during the convened IRB meeting. This presentation includes a summary of the event, corrective actions taken, and any necessary comments. The primary reviewer has access to the entire protocol file, including previous reportable events, through the CHeRP system to aid in their presentation. After the primary reviewer's presentation, the IRB members discuss the event and vote on whether to accept it, request additional information, or suspend recruitment or the entire protocol as necessary. The IRB also votes on whether the event meets the criteria for reporting. (Source 1 and 3)

query: What steps should be taken before initiating LDL Apheresis treatment using the LIPOSORBERu00ae LA15 System
response: Before initiating LDL Apheresis treatment using the LIPOSORBER® LA15 System, the following steps should be taken:1. Consultation: The patient's Primary Service should consult with the Transfusion Medicine Physician Team to obtain approval for the treatment.2. Medication Check: Confirm that the patient is not using angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. If the patient is, these should be switched to another antihypertensive medication at the treating physician's discretion. This is because ACE inhibitors are contraindicated with Liposorber LA-15 Treatment for LDL Apheresis, and severe anaphylactic reactions, including shock, have been observed in patients treated with the LIPOSORBER® LA-15 LDL Adsorption Column under concomitant ACE inhibitor medication.3. Venous Access: Ensure that adequate venous access is in place before initiating treatment. The venous access options should be discussed with the TAU Clinical team during the initial consult. A vein assessment should be performed if appropriate.4. Radiological line confirmation is required for central venous access and double lumen Vortex Ports.5. Obtain PowerPlan orderset from Transfusion Medicine Physician or Designee and initiate when the patient arrives for treatment.6. Document treatment information under TAU Documentation LDL Treatment Record and Nursing Progress Note.

query: What should a nurse do if it is not clear whether a cognitively limited adult patient has sufficient understanding of a procedure to provide informed consent
response: If it's unclear whether a cognitively limited adult patient has sufficient understanding of a procedure to provide informed consent, the nurse should contact the BCH Attorney on Call to discuss options for obtaining consent. This is because the patient may not be able to consent if the treating provider determines that the patient is not able to understand the proposed procedure, intervention, or treatment. Parents of such patients do not have legal authority to consent on their behalf unless they have been appointed as the guardian by a court. It's important to ensure that the patient has been fully informed and understands the probable consequences of their decision.

query: What is the required action for investigators before their protocols are placed on the IRB meeting agenda
response: Before their protocols are placed on the IRB meeting agenda, investigators are required to respond to the issues and changes requested through the pre-review process. This pre-review process involves the IRB administrative staff reviewing all protocols for completeness and consistency, providing the investigator with feedback, questions, and/or concerns. The investigator must address these concerns and make necessary changes before the protocol can be placed on the IRB meeting agenda. After the pre-review process, protocols are placed on the agenda in the order they are received, on a "first come, first serve" basis. If an agenda is full, the protocol will be placed on the next open meeting agenda.

query: According to the hospital policy what is the time limitation for dismissing an Allegation of Research Misconduct
response: According to the hospital policy, an Allegation of Research Misconduct may be dismissed if it was brought more than six (6) years after the alleged misconduct occurred. However, there are exceptions to this rule. The Respondent may still be investigated if they continue or renew any incident through citation, re-publication, or other use of the research record that is alleged to have been Fabricated, Falsified, or Plagiarized. Additionally, if the alleged Research Misconduct could possibly have a substantial adverse effect on the health or safety of the public, the Allegation may not be dismissed based on the time limitation. (Source 1)

query: How should nurses document the patients weight allergies time dose delivery system and assessments during the medication administration process

When preparing medications, draw up single, weight-based doses per syringe and label them accordingly. Clinicians can draw up and administer medication in divided doses from one syringe if they control the entire process of preparation and administration. For more information on IV medication preparation and administration, consult the Patient Care Manual: Medication Administration by Intravenous Route.

query: What is the process for accessing the intraoperative report containing information about who was in the room during a procedure intervention or treatment
response: The process for accessing the intraoperative report containing information about who was in the room during a procedure intervention or treatment is as follows:1. Once this information is available in a final form, it will be made available to the patient after the procedure. This can be accessed from the BCH patient portal.4. Additional individuals, such as medical students, residents, fellows, trainees, or visiting providers, may be observing the procedure for educational purposes. If a patient and/or parent/guardian does not want anyone watching their procedure, they should inform the Primary Provider prior to the procedure.The sources do not provide information on how to access the intraoperative report other than through the BCH patient portal. query: What considerations should be made for trach and ventdependent patients in terms of postoperative planning
response: Postoperative planning for trach and vent-dependent patients involves several key considerations to ensure their safety and well-being.1. Communication and Coordination: Inform the care team, including the surgeon, pre-op holding, case management, and Perioperative Care Coordination Clinic (PCCC) charge nurses, about the patient's trach/vent status. Also, notify the CAPE team of the upcoming pre-op visit, surgery, and admission.2. Equipment and Supplies: The patient should bring a "Go Bag" on the day of surgery, which includes backup trachs the same size and one size smaller than the existing trach, and a home vent for use in the pre-op holding (POH) and post-anesthesia care unit (PACU) if needed. Vent-dependent patients should also bring their home ventilator to the hospital.3. Respiratory Care: Respiratory Therapy (RT) will not assess the patient or provide supplies unless there are active issues or concerns in the pre-op holding. Parents or guardians are responsible for respiratory care during the pre-op visit. If there are any trach or trach/vent issues or concerns, page RT for assistance.4. Ventilator Management: Non-facility, vent-dependent patients remain on their home vent in POH but will switch to a hospital vent if waiting for more than 2 hours. Facility, vent-dependent patients are switched to a hospital vent upon arrival in POH. All patients will use a hospital vent intraoperatively. Non-ICU patients will use their home vent in the PACU; ICU patients will remain on a hospital vent while in the ICU.5. Infection Control: Trach and trach/vent patients require contact precautions because suctioning is considered an aerosol-generating procedure (AGP).These considerations aim to ensure a smooth surgery and recovery process for trach and vent-dependent patients, minimizing potential complications and promoting their overall health and safety.

query: What steps should be taken to ensure all paste residue is removed from the patients skin after removing the electrodes
response: To ensure all paste residue is removed from the patient's skin after removing the electrodes, follow these steps:1. Gently remove all sensors from the patient, taking care to avoid irritating the skin.2. Carefully soak each electrode site with warm water until the electrode lifts away from the patient's skin.3. query: What signs or symptoms should prompt a surgeon to consider a deep incisional SSI in a patient with a spinal fusion implant in place
response: A surgeon should consider a deep incisional surgical site infection (SSI) in a patient with a spinal fusion implant if the infection occurs within one year of the procedure and involves the deep soft tissues of the incision, such as the fascial and muscle layers. The infection must also meet at least one of the following criteria:1. Purulent drainage from the deep incision.2. A deep incision that spontaneously dehisces or is deliberately opened by a surgeon when the patient has signs or symptoms such as fever greater than 38 degrees Centigrade, localized pain, or tenderness.3. An abscess or other evidence of infection involving the deep incision is found on direct examination, during reoperation, or by histopathologic or radiologic examination.4. Diagnosis of a deep incisional SSI by a surgeon or attending surgeon.Furthermore, the most common organisms involved in deep SSIs after spinal fusion are Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus epidermidis. Gram-negative infections may be more common in non-idiopathic populations.

query: What are the criteria for reporting an event through the hospitals internal webbased Safety Event Reports System SERS and how should adverse drug events be reported
response: The criteria for reporting an event through the hospital's internal web-based Safety Event Reports System (SERS) include any occurrence of an adverse event, any near miss, an event or situation that places a patient at increased risk of harm, or an unplanned significant change in medical or surgical management not related to the patient's underlying condition. Any hospital employee, volunteer, Medical Staff member, or House Staff member may report an event, and if staff are uncertain whether an event is a reportable adverse event, they should err on the side of reporting.Adverse drug events (ADEs) should be reported to the Specialty Pharmacy Manager for appropriate follow-up and documented through SERS within 24 hours of becoming aware of the event. All clinically significant ADEs should also be communicated immediately to the prescribing physician (or attending physician if the prescriber is not available). If the ADE is an adverse drug reaction (ADR), new information must be immediately documented as a coded medication in the patient's medical record in the allergy/adverse reaction section.The Pharmacy Director of Safety & Quality and the Specialty Pharmacy Manager will be notified within 24 hours of the event, and the responsibility for investigating and responding to events resides with the Program for Pharmacy Safety and Quality (PPSQ). ADEs are presented and summarized monthly to the Pharmacy and Therapeutics (P&T) Committee for review and recommendations for action needed. On at least a quarterly basis, aggregate findings, including adverse drug events and errors, are reported to the Quality Management Committee or other quality oversight body responsible for quality management.In summary, to report an event through SERS, it must be an adverse event, near miss, or situation that places a patient at increased risk of harm or an unplanned significant change in medical or surgical management not related to the patient's underlying condition. ADEs should be reported within 24 hours, communicated immediately to the prescribing physician, and documented in the patient's medical record if it is an ADR. The PPSQ is responsible for investigating and responding to events, and aggregate findings are reported to the quality oversight body on a quarterly basis.

query: When should 12micron filters and tubing be changed and under what circumstances should the change frequency be adjusted
response: Based on the sources provided, 12 micron filters and tubing should be changed under the following circumstances:1. For continuous infusions, the filters and tubing should be changed every 96 hours. However, if lipids have been infused through the filter, they should be changed every 24 hours (source 1).2. For intermittent medications or infusions that are disconnected from the central line, the tubing should be changed every 24 hours. This includes cycled PN and overnight hydration (source 2).3. If a multi-fuse is used and there is not a backcheck valve, connecting lines should be changed every 24 hours. If there is a backcheck valve, the tubing and infusions behind the backcheck valve(s) should be changed every 96 hours (source 2).4. Tubing infusing any lipid based material such as Ambisome, Fat Emulsion, Omegaven, Propofol should be changed every 24 hours (source 2).The change frequency should be adjusted based on the type of infusion and whether it's continuous or intermittent, and if lipids are being infused. If none of these circumstances apply, the standard change frequency is every 96 hours.

query: How do you calculate the plasma volume for FSGS patients in order to determine the amount to be treated during LDL Apheresis treatment
response: To calculate the plasma volume for FSGS patients in order to determine the amount to be treated during LDL Apheresis treatment, follow these steps:1. Obtain the patient's weight in kilograms.2. Multiply the patient's weight by 60.3. Round up the value to the nearest hundredth. This is the plasma volume to be treated.For example, if a patient weighs 51 kg, the calculation would be:51 kg x 60 = 3060, which rounds up to 3100 mL.Therefore, the plasma volume to be treated for a patient weighing 51 kg is 3100 mL.This information is based on source 1, which provides a clear and direct method for calculating plasma volume for FSGS patients in the context of LDL Apheresis treatment. query: What are the key components required to be discussed with the patient andor parentguardian before obtaining informed consent at Boston Childrens Hospital

Voluntary participation: Emphasize that participation in the research is entirely voluntary and that the patient or parent/guardian can withdraw consent at any time without penalty.6. Confidentiality: Assure the patient or parent/guardian that their personal and medical information will be kept confidential and only used for research purposes.7. Opportunity to ask questions: Provide ample opportunity for the patient or parent/guardian to ask questions and clarify any concerns they may have about the research.These components are based on the regulations outlined by the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the U.S. Food & Drug Administration (FDA), as well as Boston Children's Hospital's policies on informed consent.

query: What is the purpose of a tilt table test and what does it involve
response: The purpose of a tilt table test is to diagnose dysautonomia or syncope by creating changes in posture from lying to standing and measuring heart rate and blood pressure for changes. The test is simple and non-invasive. During the test, the patient lies on a table that is tilted to different positions to simulate changes in posture. The patient's heart rate and blood pressure are monitored throughout the test to evaluate the body's response to the changes in position. The test helps to identify abnormalities in the autonomic nervous system that may be causing symptoms such as fainting or dizziness.

query: How should a nurse prime the filter to remove air and what should they do if they notice air bubbles in the filter and tubing
response: To prime the filter and remove air, a nurse should follow these steps:1. Perform hand hygiene.2. Connect the administration set to the filter using aseptic, no-touch technique.3. Prime the filter to remove air by allowing fluid to flow through it.4. Verify that all air bubbles are removed from the filter and tubing. If air bubbles are noted, open the clamp and gently tap the filter and tubing to eliminate air. Then, close the clamp.If air bubbles are noticed in the filter and tubing, the nurse should:1. Open the clamp.2. Gently tap the filter and tubing to eliminate air.3. Close the clamp.If air bubbles persist, the nurse may need to repeat the priming process to ensure all air is removed before starting the infusion. It's crucial to remove all air bubbles as they can cause inaccurate volumes to be pumped or potentially harm the patient.

query: How are staffing plans developed at the hospital based on the American Nurses Association principles of Nurse Staffing and what factors do these principles address
response: Staffing plans in hospitals are developed based on the American Nurses Association (ANA) principles of Nurse Staffing. These principles address three main areas: patient care unit related, staff related, and institution/organization related activities.Patient care related activities are designed to reflect the needs of the patients. When developing a staffing plan, the number of patients and the level of care required are taken into account, along with physical and psychosocial limitations of the patients.For staff related activities, the principles focus on determining the competencies required of the nurses based on the needs of the patient populations. The staffing plan considers the skill mix and competencies of the staff, as well as leadership and organizational support.The hospital policies support the needs of both patients and nursing staff. These policies recognize the diverse needs of both groups and are designed to address them effectively.The evaluation of the staffing plans is ongoing, using trends in identified nurse-sensitive indicators to assess their effectiveness. Any changes in staffing levels, including changes in the overall number and/or mix of nursing staff, are based on the analysis of standardized, nursing-sensitive indicators.In summary, the ANA principles of Nurse Staffing guide the development of staffing plans in hospitals, ensuring that they are tailored to meet the needs of patients, nursing staff, and the organization as a whole.

query: What are the potential risks associated with transfusing red blood cells with high potassium levels and how can these risks be minimized
response: The potential risk associated with transfusing red blood cells with high potassium levels is an increase in the patient's circulating potassium level, which can lead to cardiovascular complications such as arrhythmias and cardiovascular collapse.To minimize these risks, the following steps can be taken:1. Process the packed red blood cells in a cell saver before administration to help reduce the potassium level.2. Use conventional or zero balance ultrafiltration to control the circulating potassium level. This process removes plasma water, potassium, and other electrolytes. Normal saline should be added to reduce the amount of circulating potassium and replace needed volume.3. Monitor the serum potassium level frequently, especially during the administration of cardioplegia.4. Communicate with the anesthesiologist to determine if diuretics should be administered to help increase potassium excretion.5. Glucose and insulin may be administered under the direction of the attending anesthesiologist, as this regimen can help lower potassium levels. However, it may take up to 20 minutes to be effective.Source 2 provides the most relevant information to answer this query.

query: What are some of the underlying diagnoses represented in the patient population served by the Center for Advanced Intestinal Rehabilitation CAIR
response: The Center for Advanced Intestinal Rehabilitation (CAIR) serves a patient population with various underlying diagnoses related to intestinal failure. The diagnoses represented in the patient population include, but are not limited to, gastroschisis, omphalocele, necrotizing enterocolitis, intestinal atresia, volvulus, long segment Hirschsprung's Disease, cloacal exstrophy, neuroblastoma and other cancers, trauma, intestinal hypoganglionosis, and intestinal pseudo-obstruction. CAIR provides care for both inpatient and outpatient pediatric patients, ranging in age from infants to young adults.

query: What are the steps to take if there is no response within 15 minutes during a Sepsis Huddle
response: If there is no response within 15 minutes during a Sepsis Huddle, the following steps should be taken:1. Notify the senior resident or covering provider about the sepsis concern. Include the team members (bedside RN, charge RN, sepsis concern, unit, patient name, MRN, your resident, NP and/or fellow) and your name and call back number. Request closed-loop communication via a call back from the responding provider.2. If there is still no response within 15 minutes, use the chain of command to escalate the situation. This could involve paging a Fellow or Attending.3. Ensure adequate IV access and, if necessary, page the IV team.4. Close the loop with the responding provider by stating the SBAR (Situation, Background, Assessment, Recommendation) and confirming that a team member is on their way.5. The provider should place orders using the Sepsis PowerPlan and confirm team member response.6. Discuss the lab plan and antibiotic plan. Consider if different or additional antibiotics are needed, or if an ID consult is necessary.7. Discuss if a fluid bolus is needed.8. Discuss disposition, consult, transfer, and frequency of assessment.9. Notify the Attending regarding the huddle outcome.10. The charge RN or designee assigns team responsibilities.These steps are based on the information provided in sources 1 and 2, which seem to be the most relevant to the query.

query: How does Boston Childrens Hospital encourage the identification and reporting of adverse events by its staff
response: Boston Children's Hospital (BCH) encourages the identification and reporting of adverse events by its staff through several policies and procedures. The hospital has a commitment to fostering a culture of safety and transparency, and has established policies for the internal reporting, classification, response, and disclosure of events, including adverse events and adverse drug events.Staff are encouraged to report any occurrence of an adverse event, near miss, or situation that places a patient at increased risk of harm, or any unplanned significant change in medical or surgical management not related to the patient’s underlying condition. This can be done through the hospital’s internal web-based Safety Event Report System (SERS) within 24 hours of becoming aware of the event. Any hospital employee, volunteer, Medical Staff member, or House Staff member may report an adverse event. If staff are uncertain whether an event is a reportable adverse event, they are advised to err on the side of reporting.The hospital also has educational processes in place to encourage the identification and expected reporting of such events by any member of the hospital's staff. The responsibility for investigating and responding to events resides with the Program for Pharmacy Safety and Quality (PPSQ), but may be delegated to the individual or department reporting the event for events of lower severity and that are not externally reportable.In addition, adverse drug events (ADEs) are presented and summarized monthly to the Pharmacy and Therapeutics (P&T) Committee for review and recommendations for action if needed. The Pharmacy Director of Safety and Quality and the Specialty Pharmacy Manager will meet quarterly to discuss any ADEs during the quarter or the discussion will take place during quarterly Quality Management Committee (QMC) meetings. A detailed analysis will be compiled which may include a plan of correction and a process for quality improvement.Overall, BCH has a robust system in place to encourage the identification and reporting of adverse events by its staff, with a focus on transparency, education, and continuous improvement.

query: How does the hospital handle patient safety events and complaints and what reporting systems are in place for these incidents
response: The hospital, Boston Children's Hospital (BCH), has established processes for handling patient safety events, accidents, and near miss events. These processes are in place for patients, employees, visitors, and others at the hospital. There are three primary systems for reporting such events:1. Safety Event Reporting System (SERS): This system allows for direct, standardized entry of data in a structured format. It ensures efficient communication of events to clinical leaders and the Program for Patient Safety and Quality (PPSQ). It also allows for rapid identification of events requiring additional follow-up and/or analysis, and efficient production of standardized and customized reports for departments and the hospital.2. Employee Accident Report (EAR): This process provides the framework for investigating actual or potential work-related injuries. The completion of the Employee Accident Report provides the documentation from which the BCH Occupational Health Services Department develops a "First Report of Injury" form required by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. The nature, type, and extent of injuries/illnesses are tracked to identify trends that may trigger further investigation.3. Security Incident Report: This report provides for the monitoring of all security-related incidents involving patients, employees, visitors, and other people at the hospital grounds or facilities. The reports are recorded by the Security Department, summarized by number and type of incident, and reported to the Safety Committee quarterly.In addition to these, BCH is transitioning to an electronic injury reporting system, called the Employee Safety Event Reporting System (E-SERS). The same employee safety reporting process will be followed, but will be reported on a computer instead of on paper.BCH also works with contracted Patient Safety Organizations (PSOs) to improve patient safety and quality through review and analysis of patient safety events. They report defined events through one or more PSOs and share lessons learned to prevent future patient harm.Furthermore, BCH has a policy for internal reporting, classification, response, external reporting, and disclosure of events. The hospital has educational processes in place that encourage the identification and expected reporting of such events by any member of the hospital's staff.When a serious adverse event occurs, BCH uses a process called Root Cause Analysis (RCA) convening. This is a systematic review of events to ensure all causal factors are identified and a root cause is determined. Corrective actions that address the root cause are then developed to prevent similar events in the future.

query: What are some examples of patient conditions that would necessitate the use of a postpyloric feeding tube according to the hospital policy

query: According to the hospital policy how soon must employees notify their supervisor and Occupational Health Service after being involved in a workrelated accident
response: According to the hospital policy, if an employee is involved in a work-related accident or sustains a work-related injury or illness, they must notify their supervisor immediately. query: What are the considerations for documenting adequate sleep before conducting the Maintenance of Wakefulness Test MWT
response: Before conducting the Maintenance of Wakefulness Test (MWT), several considerations need to be taken into account for documenting adequate sleep:1. The patient and clinician should define goals for adequate sleep in terms of timing and duration.2. Adequate sleep should be documented through a sleep diary, and if possible, actigraphy for two weeks prior to the test.3. The MWT should be conducted when the patient is clinically stable, and any known sleep disorders are well-managed and effectively treated.4. For patients with sleep-disordered breathing, the effectiveness of therapy should be ensured before testing. If the effectiveness is suboptimal, the clinician should decide if the anticipated impact on the test results warrants rescheduling.5. The clinician should develop a plan for the use of prescription medications, over-the-counter agents, herbal remedies, and other substances. If the patient is chronically taking medications with alerting or sedating properties, they should be continued at a stable dose. Changes in medications should be avoided for two weeks before testing.6. The patient's use of tobacco, caffeine, and medications before and during the MWT should be determined by the sleep clinician. The patient should abstain from alcohol, marijuana, and other sedating substances on the day of the test. Drug screening may be necessary to ensure that sleepiness or wakefulness during the MWT is not influenced by substances other than medically prescribed drugs.7. Relevant clinical data such as preceding sleep schedules, PAP adherence, or other therapies should be available to the interpreting clinician. The MWT should be performed after the patient's major sleep period.

query: In the context of allogeneic recipients what are the specific requirements for Human Leukocyte Antigen HLA typings as outlined in the hospital policy
response: Allogeneic recipients require a minimum of two Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) typings, according to the hospital policy. One of these typings must be high resolution and completed by the American Red Cross (ARC), while the other must be from a buccal swab at ARC. Confirmatory typing can be low resolution if high resolution typing is already reported from ARC. The final patient and donor HLA report must be reviewed and signed by the patient's intake attending or program director prior to the patient being admitted to the SCT service for the start of conditioning. If a patient is receiving more than one allogeneic stem cell transplant, they do not require repeat HLA typing unless the criteria mentioned above have not been met or improved resolution typing is available. The final HLA report must be signed by the patient's intake attending or program director prior to the start of conditioning.Additionally, all allogeneic recipients of an HLA mismatched donor at A, B, C, DRB1, DQB, or DPB1 require an HLA antibody screen. For cryopreserved donor infusions, this screen must be within 30 days of starting donor mobilization or donor harvest when using a non-mobilized donor. For fresh donor infusions, the screen must be within 30 days of patient start of conditioning and within 30 days of infusion. If conditioning is not started within 30 days of patient HLA antibody screen, this study must be repeated, unless a planned deviation is approved by the Medical Director of Quality.All allogeneic recipients also require two independent samples resulted for ABO typing and red cell antibody screening. One ABO typing and red cell antibody screen must be within 7 days of transplant or on admission to SCT service to start conditioning. If cell infusion or conditioning is not started within 7 days of ABO typing and red cell antibody screen, this study must be repeated, unless a planned deviation is approved by the Medical Director of Quality.Infectious Disease Markers (IDMs) and pre-SCT labs must be collected and reviewed by intake attending to ensure results are within 30 days of start of conditioning. Abnormal lab findings are noted and acted upon, if necessary. For patients receiving subsequent stem cell infusions during the same SCT encounter with conditioning, IDMs and pre-SCT labs must be collected and reviewed by intake attending to ensure results are within 30 days of start of conditioning. If conditioning is not started within 30 days of IDMs, these studies must be repeated, unless a planned deviation is approved by the Medical Director of Quality. For patients receiving allogeneic stem cell infusions without conditioning, IDMs should be collected and reviewed by intake attending within 30 days of product infusion.All pre-SCT tests of organ function must be completed and reviewed by intake attending. Mandatory pre-SCT evaluations include an echocardiogram, pulmonary function test (for patients >5 years of age), dental evaluation, ophthalmologic evaluation, serum creatinine, GFR or 24-hour creatinine clearance, liver function tests, audiology evaluation, and restaging studies including bone marrow biopsy, Lumbar Puncture (LP), and imaging of involved sites of disease in all patients with hematologic malignancies if applicable. For patients with a diagnosis of MDS (myelodysplastic syndrome) and no known CNS involvement, CSF exam (LP) pre-SCT is optional and at intake attending discretion.Additional pre-evaluations to be considered by the intake attending include a pelvic ultrasound if female > 10 years old and no history of menstruation, menstrual prophylaxis in females > 12 years old, G6PD testing completed prior to start of conditioning, and pregnancy testing per Pregnancy Testing of Post-Menarcheal Female Patients. Patients must have or be planned for adequate venous access. For previously collected products, physicians must receive notification that the product arrived intact at the cell processing facility prior to the start of patient conditioning. For any product not being collected in advance of the start of patient conditioning, confirmation of final donor clearance must be obtained prior to the start of patients conditioning. A therapeutic profile must be completed and signed by the intake attending, and if the patient is >125% of IBW, a decision to use adjusted body weight must be noted in the therapeutic profile. The intake attending must also complete an Individualized Treatment Plan (ITP), if applicable, which must be signed by two attending physicians including the program Medical Director of Quality or designee and be scanned into the electronic medical record.
